headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Interim 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Interim 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you and good morning. I'd Like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's fourth quarter and year end 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Chris Weilminster and
componenttext:
Great, thank you and good morning. I'd Like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's fourth quarter and year end 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Chris Weilminster and Jeff Berkes. 
In addition to our fourth quarter and year end 2010 supplemental disclosure package we also filed our 10-K yesterday. These documents provides you with a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trust 2010 operating and financial performance and both are currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as in depth discussion is a financial condition said results of operations. I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of fourth quarter and year end 2010 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. In trying to decide how to talk about 2010 and then set expectations for 2011 with you all today, its helpful for me to step back a bit and look top-down.I jotted down a list of some of the things we have done t
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. In trying to decide how to talk about 2010 and then set expectations for 2011 with you all today, its helpful for me to step back a bit and look top-down.
I jotted down a list of some of the things we have done this year and on reflection for our recent view. But here's what happened.
In this economy, we grew top line revenue 2.5% to a record $543 million. We grew same store, same-center property operating income 2.1% to a record $350 million.
We grew FFO per share of 2.6% to a record $388 million, with no easy prior period comparable. We grew 2010 fourth quarter FFO to $1.1 per share, first time any quarter ever had $1. We negotiated 312 new and renewal releases at positive leasing spreads, 8% cash, 18% straight line.
Maintained occupancy levels year-over-year at 93.2%. We made our first investments in Newberry Street and are performing above our underwriting.
We accretively bought up a land on the Pentagon Row on Bethesda Row. We delivered our hand in laying at Bethesda project on time, on budget, and fully leased. We increased our footprint at Escondido in San Diego, at Huntington in Long Island and recently in our third property in Florida just outside of Fort Lauderdale.
We completed and leased up most of our office building in Santana, we broke around on our 108-unit residential building there and we've accelerated our plans to build the next one. 
We signed our deal with AvalonBay as square. we negotiated deal on which is loosely amnesty approved by the MBTA. We hope to break ground on this project late 2011 or early 2012.
The overall White Flint sector plan and our Mid-Pike messing plan was approved. Making way for first phase construction at Mid-Pike which is tentatively to begin in, 2012. And we did increase our dividend rate of common shares for the 43rd year in a row.
The 2010 was a very good year for us and 2011 should be too. Even though we'll be hit pretty badly in the short-term by the Borders bankruptcy, along with some of the other non-recurring lease termination fees that we'll talk about.
We've got a lot done in 2010 and while we didn't deploy as much capital as we would have liked to big acquisitions, we created a lot of value in what we did do and we clearly saw a pick up under our product as the year progressed.
We're able to close on our Tower Shops in Florida last month and expect a more active 2011 from that perspective. Though at the moment, I'd stay more optimistic even about the future value creation redevelopment we've identified.
I went back and look at the forward-looking comments I made on this call back in August and then again, in November, concerning our view of the major market, as well as the leasing and operating environment. And I've got to say, it all still applies and is generally moving in the right direction. Retailers want to get deals done in virtually all the markets we have business in but with a tough conscious mentality that's here to stay.
Basically its harder for us to create a more valuable company simply by raising rents. Having said that, Washington D.C. remains the steadiest and strongest of our markets with California improving the fastest, particularly at Santana Row and 3rd Street Promenade in Santa Monica. Lot's more value for us to add for both of those California properties.
I mentioned Borders a minute ago, let me put a finer point on that. The troubles at Borders booked will defer us in 2011, no doubt. We have 4 Borders locations paying a total of $3 million in rent, about $0.05 a share and they stop paying rent in February. 
Certainly, that income stream is a risk in the short run. When you think about it in the longer-term, Borders has effective drug to the shopping centers that they're in for a number of years now and I can imagine that's going to change anytime soon no matter how the situation gets resolved.
So if you're us, you can understand why we would be anxious to work through these deals as quickly as possible so that we can really look at those prime locations to help your TATs. An intense effort to uncover additional value creative opportunities throughout the portfolio, has beefing up in our leasing and redevelopment staff. Additional residential opportunities on our existing land look very possible at places like Congressional Plaza, like Bethesda, like Charlie Dent, like Barracks Road and others not to mention our large developments in Mid-Pike and Assembly and still more to come at Santana Row. Lots of optimism around here on that potential.
In summary, despite we remain a very challenging economic environment, it is improving one. And our path of future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. That value will be led by retail and nonretail redevelopment and refinancing opportunities along with new raw material in the form of some pretty good acquisitions that we're making progress on, tower Shops in Davie, Florida is a good start.
That's all I got for my prepared remarks this morning. Let me turn it over to Andy and look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Now I really have sentiments and I continue to be impressed by how solid our performance has been over the past three years of this and how we're positioned for the future.Think about this. 2008 property operatin
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Now I really have sentiments and I continue to be impressed by how solid our performance has been over the past three years of this and how we're positioned for the future.
Think about this. 2008 property operating income was higher than 2007. 2009 was higher than 2008, 2010 was higher than 2009. We're expecting 2011 to be higher than 2010.
We avoided material impairments, we achieved positive lease roll over every year and in fact every quarter, maintained strong and steady occupancy, maintained a conservative balance sheet with no significant equity delusion, we've paid an increasing all cash dividend on our common shares.  There are few of any public real estate companies that can match that performance over the prior three years.
Turning now to our results, let's start with the quarter. Same-store property operating income came in at a positive 0.8% including redevelopments and positive 1.1% excluding redevelopments for the quarter. This was despite the negative impact we've discussed before from the loss of the Home Depot lease termination fee in Flourtown in Philly. The drivers of this growth were continued steady occupancy and an increase in minimum rent by 3.8%, driven by the consistency of our operating portfolio and supported by redevelopment impacts of properties like in Bethesda and London Square.
The full impact of this increase in minimum rent doesn't show up in the rental income line because it was all set by recoveries, which were down 11% for the quarter. Largely driven by significantly lower snow removal cost in this year's fourth quarter compared to 2009.
Along the operating line we saw decreases in interest expense as we held significant cash balances at the end of 2009 before repaying the last of our term loan in the third quarter of 2010. 
G&A increased $1.33 million through increases in acquisition, development and personnel costs. All in, FFO per share clips the dollar mark for the first time ever at $1.1 for the quarter. 
Moving now to the full-year 2010. As Don mentioned, we produced record topline revenue in 2010 on flat 93.2% year-over-year occupancy. 
Once again, bullied by positive full year lease roll overs of 8%. Same-store property operating income grew 2.3% including redevelopment, and 2.1% excluding redevelopment. 
Continued growth in property operating income, G&A control and balance sheet management, not just not but throughout the past several years, contributed to our record FFO of $239 million or $3.88 per share, and that bulk fee considering the operating environment over that period.
Another item to note in our 2010 financials. You may have seen in our disclosure that we received a final judgment relating to our appeal of 350 Winchester litigation at Santana Row. We're disappointed in losing our appeal with the associated $60.2 million payment of the matter. However, the full amount have been accrued in '09, there's no significant new earnings impact related to this final roll in fourth quarter results, we do not expect any related earnings to our existing 2011.
You need to expand and redevelopment disclosure in the 8-K. Our goal is to provide more detail on value creation opportunities we'll be pursuing over the next several years. Including that were increases discussion of larger project, Assembly Row and Mid-Pike. 
Last quarter, Don gave an update on Assembly Row in a recent agreement with AvalonBay. And at that time, we are still working through final approvals for our new Orange Line T station at the site. . 
Last week, we announced the MBTA had unanimously devoted in support of the interim of understanding with Federal Realty for the construction of the T station.
This marks a big step forward with respect to the T-Stop at Assembly Row becoming our value. Phase one of Assembly Row, which we done partnership with AvalonBay, will include three buildings, totaling 419 residential units, plus 280,000 square feet of retail, all in addition to the existing 337,000 square-foot power center at The Assembly Square marketplace.
AvalonBay will build the two residential buildings with 110,000 square feet of retail on the ground form. Buy back the retail shells, similar to what we did at Rockville Town Square. 
Federal will build the remaining 180,000 square foot retail building. We began actively leasing the project with the opening of our marketing center late last year, and are already seeing interest from users. Total Phase One costs are expect to be about $100 million to $125 million range.
In North Bethesda, our overall sketch plans for the redevelopment of Mid-Pike Plaza was approved on January 20, allowing us to move forward on submitting a plan for that project's first phase in April, with the anticipated approval later this year. With all approvals in place, we may be able to begin construction in mid-2012, on the approximately $200 million first phase to include 240,000 square feet of retail and office space, and approximately 400 residential units and appropriate parking.
The phasing of the project means the remainder of the center will be open and operating during construction, which allows us to continue receiving a steady stream of income through stabilization of the first phase.
Future phases of the project will be timed according to the success of the first phase, but the total project is anticipated to include over 3 million square feet of Commercial Real Estate with filled out over the next 10 to 15 years.
Moving on to guidance. We're leaving our 2011 FFO per share guidance of $3.95 to $4.02 unchanged. Obviously, the news out of Borders this morning with $3 million or $0.05 per share of contribution makes it more difficult for us. And as a result, we'd certainly guided to the lower end of the range.
Having said that, it's only February and there are many positives or negatives that can happen throughout the year. We certainly believe any hit in the near term will be longer-term opportunity to create value going forward, as Don said. Operator, we will now turn the call over for your question.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] In the first question comes from the line of Clinton Valley from Citi.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to ask Jeff to kind of talk a little bit more about this. But let me give you a point of view on this. It is just crazy to pay some of the numbers that are being required on very flat, very hopefully stable, basic core assets without reall
componenttext: Well, I'm going to ask Jeff to kind of talk a little bit more about this. But let me give you a point of view on this. It is just crazy to pay some of the numbers that are being required on very flat, very hopefully stable, basic core assets without really any potential to add value to them. We all know what our cost capital is and it's just a lot of the stuff we're seeing won't allow that to happen. When you talk about the opportunity to put six to seven acres together and effectively carry it, the sixth is going in and then stabilize the seventh, with a bunch of acreage left, that looks attractive to us. That we can see it pass the value creation. So we got to be able to see that path whether it's on the form of larger properties, which we always like, because I do believe you can do a lot more comes up down the road when you've got the acreage there, or whether it is in the few of the places where you have some undervalued acres or in terms of rent that are being pay, either one that works for us. But yes, I think it's reasonable to assume that you should expect to see bigger type of assets generally on the acquisition side for us because there's got to be a way to create value added for us to do with.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, you're absolutely right. If there's an asset today that comes to the market that's institutional quality and one of the better trade areas in the East and West Coast, that's relatively easy to underwrite, that doesn't have any existin
componenttext: Just to add to that, you're absolutely right. If there's an asset today that comes to the market that's institutional quality and one of the better trade areas in the East and West Coast, that's relatively easy to underwrite, that doesn't have any existing debt attached to it, the pricing is spectacular. We're back down into the cap rate range of significantly below six. And with reasonable assumptions going forward, IRR is, in some cases, are below even 7% or maybe, slightly above 7%. So clearly, chasing those assets and paying those prices when they're so value-added proposition does really makes no sense. So we're focused on things where we think we can generate returns exceed our longer-term cost of capital. Like Don said, those are generally going to be bigger deals.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, with IRRs, as well as that to be stabilized assets that you sort of looking at selling any quality assets that don't have this higher growth profile?
componenttext: I guess, with IRRs, as well as that to be stabilized assets that you sort of looking at selling any quality assets that don't have this higher growth profile?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we always consider that, particularly when we're doing an all-cash acquisition. But it's a matter of balance for us because a lot of our assets, we've owned for a long time, we have added a lot of value to, have a very low tax basis. And we won't do
componenttext: Well, we always consider that, particularly when we're doing an all-cash acquisition. But it's a matter of balance for us because a lot of our assets, we've owned for a long time, we have added a lot of value to, have a very low tax basis. And we won't do anything that would create a capital gain impact situation. And of course we balance that with earnings as well but we do constantly look at the portfolio and when we have the opportunity to through a cash acquisition, do a Verse 1031 exchange, we definitely consider that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got, Chris, after this in a second. We've got four. We've got one at Santana Row in the flagship position. We'll have lots of opportunities to read 10 in that space. That in some ways is the toughest for us because it's in such an important par
componenttext: Yes, we've got, Chris, after this in a second. We've got four. We've got one at Santana Row in the flagship position. We'll have lots of opportunities to read 10 in that space. That in some ways is the toughest for us because it's in such an important part space at Santana that it needs to be the right tenant to do that. It's interesting for me, that's a really interesting one because Borders hasn't been adding to that property for a long time now. And it sits in a very important part of the project yet the project continues to get better. So this is a real opportunity for us at Santana to be able to kind of re-merchandise that with the 2011, '12, '13 type of tenant that will be great for the future. Friendship Center, down Maryland, great thought. In fact, Chris, I know we have a bunch of things working on that spot already. Old Town Center in Los Gatos, California, that has to be re-done in Wynnewood on the main line and outside of Philadelphia. So if you think about those four locations, we're going to have our transfers, that's for sure at.

componenttext: It is and that's a big word for me. Not so much or as much about the tenants above that survived but just like Bed Bath & Beyond without linens and just like Best Buy without Circuit City, Barnes without Borders is kind of a better negotiating position. And so I kind of worry about how that's all going to play out. Certainly, a very well run company and doing things that should allow them to be better prepared for the new economy. But we've got work to do to make sure that we're protecting our properties there. I don't know how that will turn out, we'll see in the next couple of years.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: You know what? Stronger in the better properties and flatter in the B's and C's and really, nothing new from that prospective. Where I feel pretty good is kind of looking hard at the land that we already own throughout this portfolio. And that's at existi
componenttext: You know what? Stronger in the better properties and flatter in the B's and C's and really, nothing new from that prospective. Where I feel pretty good is kind of looking hard at the land that we already own throughout this portfolio. And that's at existing shopping centers, as well as the big projects in Mid-Pike, which really should be a good one and Assembly. So when I look at those things, I do see with no land costs because we own those properties already. The ability to put money to work at general enhancing of values where I am most optimistic when it comes to the day in and day out leasing, it's a real mixed bag, man. There is strong demand and we are seeing some ability to get better rents in key spots at great properties. But it's tough in the average and even in the above average stuff. So there's a real dichotomy there.

componenttext: Jeffrey, we had some reserve. We had some of the receivable reserves at the end of last year. This is certainly not a surprise to us in terms of Borders' health. And so while we were more optimistic that we would be able to milk them along, if you will, and renegotiate from deals outside of bankruptcy this year. That, opportunity is gone and so that opportunity almost have to create additional hits above what we had anticipated in the guidance. But I've got to say, that will hit us but it's February and good things and bad things will happen for the rest of the year. So we'll see how it turn out.

componenttext: Yes, and very, very market focused here. When you look at the Washington area and the small shop ability to -- first of all, ability to absorb lower sales levels over the past couple of years, the ones are kind of gone. And the others are operating at a different level at a new normal. They have been able to find some of the financing that they haven't been able to. To the extent they're new. And things have settled pretty good. That's different, I'll tell you in a couple of properties we still see in Florida, it's still a bloodbath from what we see in terms of the small shop there. It's a completely different world than it is outside of Washington D.C. At Santana and the northern California for us, a very strong recovery, vis-Ã -vis where they were. It's very market dependent and within the market, very shopping center dependent.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Since you mentioned Florida, I'm curious if you could talk a moment about how you think the composition of your returns like long term in Florida, maybe vis-a-vis your existing assets? Because I think in the mid-Atlantic, in northeast California, people t
componenttext: Since you mentioned Florida, I'm curious if you could talk a moment about how you think the composition of your returns like long term in Florida, maybe vis-a-vis your existing assets? Because I think in the mid-Atlantic, in northeast California, people think of Federal's existing portfolios being through ashwind, undersupplied submarkets that are maybe more about mentoring than current cash flow yield? Is the opportunity in the Florida more about achieving higher current income yields than it is long-term NAV growth?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's not. It is long term NAV growth which is really what is very, very important to us. Now the issue, it's tough for us to sit back and say well, this is how it works in Florida because we really don't have a sample size to make any determination. We're
componenttext: It's not. It is long term NAV growth which is really what is very, very important to us. Now the issue, it's tough for us to sit back and say well, this is how it works in Florida because we really don't have a sample size to make any determination. We're talking about two assess that we had during the worst time in the history of Florida there. And now a new acquisition that I can tell you, or Chris can certainly tell you, the demand since we've taken it over looks extremely encouraging. So I'd like to tell you more. Our objective is always to buy real estate that will be more down the road than last. And it's not about spread investing in any of the markets that we're in. So whether we're successful or not in finding the right properties and being able to redevelop an asset. That's in the story that will be evident overtime. But that's what we're trying suggest, it's the same amount.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don is up in Boston, he's not available on the call today. But I think I can speak for him since we just had this conversation. Real and interesting things going on. Today, Assembly Square is simply not an office market today, that's just not. We get goin
componenttext: Don is up in Boston, he's not available on the call today. But I think I can speak for him since we just had this conversation. Real and interesting things going on. Today, Assembly Square is simply not an office market today, that's just not. We get going on this first phase, which will not be robust first phase, wherever it will be, somewhere between $6 million and $7 million to kind of get started there, I think, still working on those pieces. But it's all about creating a place. That plus T plus some of the other stuff that's going on will clearly make it a more attractive office environment. I will tell you there is a tenant up in Boston, it was a large tenant up in Boston, I think you know about it, that was considering our site. And wound up after a lot of due diligence choosing another that they have been far down the road on. But frankly, we left there very encouraged because it was validating that a large office player would look and considered a vision that we see for Assembly. So in talking with our brokers between that look that, that attendant made and some other things that was going there, I'm optimistic that it's not certainly not next year or the year after in terms of being able to get the right office tenant there. But down the road, 54 acres there and we will be building the first phase that takes of the small piece of that. There's absolutely opportunity or we wouldn't be doing the first phase.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the hard part of your question to answer is the timing. But what we've got when we got Tower was a very well located regional piece of land at the intersection of a busy circuit street in the freeway. That have been neglected or certainly not
componenttext: Yes, I think the hard part of your question to answer is the timing. But what we've got when we got Tower was a very well located regional piece of land at the intersection of a busy circuit street in the freeway. That have been neglected or certainly not focused on intensely over the last several years. Along with the ability to add about 80,000 square feet of GLA to the site. So there's a couple of things that we can do right away. One is getting in focus on the operations of the center, kind of the nuts and bolts and tidy things up a bit. There is plan to improve the existing physical plant which we think will go a long way towards driving NOI going forward. The there's also the ability to add additional GLA the question you asked is appropriate, and that's going to be dependent upon tenant demand, obviously. But there's definitely ability to do somethings there immediately and in the kind of medium term, if you will. They are going to really drive that NOI growth. We are very happy with the acquisition.

componenttext: Yes, it's pretty -- we're busy. There a lot of stuff to work right now that's very interesting. But all of it, again, because it's not stabilized institutional. Is it done to right sub-7 IRRs. All that's got a lot of moving parts. A lot of things that aren't in our control. Its difficult to be too predictive about what we're going to get done and when and how much. But we've got a lot of interesting things going on right now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nate, let me tell you one other thing you didn't asked about Tower Shops that I wanted to bring up with you. One of the reasons we made that acquisition or we were in a position to make that acquisition, is because we are in a position to absorb the outst
componenttext: Nate, let me tell you one other thing you didn't asked about Tower Shops that I wanted to bring up with you. One of the reasons we made that acquisition or we were in a position to make that acquisition, is because we are in a position to absorb the outstanding debt on a number of these shopping centers. In a lot of cases, that debt is above market. That's the case at Tower. What I think our due diligence and our process kind of laid out though was we've got the ability to refinance that debt. I'm not sure if you knew that frankly by looking at that property. And so the ability to buy it at $68 million, which if it didn't have above market data, that probably would get a lot higher than that. And so to the ability to buy refinance out of the above market debt and something more in line with Federal's cost of the capital providers really value-additive. So add that to conversation at Tower.

componenttext: That's what we're thinking. That's the deal. Offline we could do probably a little bit better with you. The absence of the termination fees from '10 and '09 won't be there this year and we're certainly don't having an issue at least with Borders and maybe a little bit of Barnes in '11. So when you put all that together, I think it's amazing, frankly, that you'll see some growth in '11 versus '10, versus '09 versus '08. And I know you're used to maybe looking at some other companies that have the absence of impairments and things like that the show more growth, if you will, although I think it's more accounting growth than real growth.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's fourth quarter and year end 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Chris Weilminster and
componenttext:
Great, thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's fourth quarter and year end 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Chris Weilminster and Jeff Berkes. 
In addition to our fourth quarter and year end 2010 supplemental disclosure package, we also filed our 10-K yesterday. Those documents provides you with a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trust 2010 operating and financial performance and both are currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as in depth discussion is a financial condition said results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of fourth quarter and year end 2010 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. In trying to decide how to talk about 2010 and then set expectations for 2011 with you all today, it's helpful for me to step back a bit and look top-down.I jotted down a list of some of the things we have done
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. In trying to decide how to talk about 2010 and then set expectations for 2011 with you all today, it's helpful for me to step back a bit and look top-down.
I jotted down a list of some of the things we have done this year and on reflection for our recent view. But here's what happened.
In this economy, we grew top line revenue 2.5% to a record $543 million. We grew same store, same-center property operating income 2.1% to a record $350 million.
We grew FFO per share of 2.6% to a record $388 million, with no easy prior period comparable. We grew 2010 fourth quarter FFO to $1.1 per share, first time any quarter ever hit a $1. We negotiated 312 new and renewal releases at positive leasing spreads, 8% cash, 18% straight line.
Maintained occupancy levels year-over-year at 93.2%. We made our first investments in Newberry Street and are performing above our underwriting.
We accretively bought up a land on the Pentagon Row on Bethesda Row. We delivered our hand in laying at Bethesda project on time, on budget, fully leased. We increased our footprint at Escondido in San Diego, at Huntington in Long Island and recently in our third property in Florida just outside of Fort Lauderdale.
We completed and leased up most of our office building in Santana, we broke around on our 108-unit residential building there and we've accelerated our plans to build the next one. 
We signed our deal with AvalonBay at Assembly Square. We negotiated a deal on T-Stop which is recently unanimously approved by the MBTA. We hope to break ground on this project late 2011 or early 2012.
The overall White Flint sector plan and our Mid-Pike messing plan was approved. Making way for first phase construction at Mid-Pike which is tentatively planned to begin in, 2012. And we did increase our dividend rate of common shares for the 43rd year in a row.
The 2010 was a very good year for us and 2011 should be too. Even though we'll be hit pretty badly in the short-term by the Borders bankruptcy, along with some of the other non-recurring lease termination fees that we'll talk about.
We've got a lot done in 2010 and while we didn't deploy as much capital as we would have liked to big acquisitions, we created a lot of value in what we did do and we clearly saw a pickup in desirable products as the year progressed.
We were able to close on our Tower Shops in Florida last month and expect a more active 2011 from that perspective. Though at the moment, I'd say I'm more optimistic even about the future value creation through redevelopment we've identified.
I went back and look at the forward-looking comments I made on this call back in August and then again, in November, concerning our view of the major market, as well as the leasing and operating environment. And I've got to say, it all still applies and is generally moving in the right direction. Retailers want to get deals done in virtually all the markets we have business in but with a tough cost-conscious mentality that's here to stay.
Basically its harder for us to create a more valuable company simply by raising rents. Having said that, Washington D.C. remains the steadiest and strongest of our markets with California improving the fastest, particularly at Santana Row and 3rd Street Promenade in Santa Monica. Lots more value for us to add for both of those California properties.
I mentioned Borders a minute ago, let me put a finer point on that. The troubles at Borders booked will defer us in 2011, no doubt. We have 4 Borders locations paying a total of $3 million in rent and extras, about $0.05 a share, and they stopped paying rent in February. 
Certainly, that income stream is at risk in the short run. But when you think about it in the longer-term, Borders hasn't really been an effective draw to the shopping centers that they're in for a number of years now. I can't imagine how that's going to change anytime soon no matter how the situation gets resolved.
So if you're us, you can understand why we'd be anxious to work through these deals as quickly as possible so that we can really look at those prime locations to help your TATs. An intense effort to uncover additional value creative opportunities throughout the portfolio, has been beefing up on our leasing and redevelopment staff. Additional residential opportunities on our existing land look very possible at places like Congressional Plaza, like Bethesda, like Shirlington, like Barracks Road and others, not to mention our large developments in Mid-Pike and Assembly and still more to come at Santana Row. Lots of optimism around here on that potential.
In summary, despite what remains a very challenging economic environment, it is an improving one. And our path of future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. That value will be lead by retail and non-retail redevelopment and retenanting opportunities, along with new raw material in the form of some pretty good acquisitions that we're making progress on, Tower Shops in Davie, Florida is a good start.
That's all I got for my prepared remarks this morning. Let me now turn it over to Andy and I look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Now I really have Don's sentiments and I continue to be impressed by how solid our performance has been over the past three years of this [Audio Gap] and how we're positioned for the future.Think about this. 2008
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Now I really have Don's sentiments and I continue to be impressed by how solid our performance has been over the past three years of this [Audio Gap] and how we're positioned for the future.
Think about this. 2008 property operating income was higher than 2007. 2009 was higher than 2008, 2010 was higher than 2009. We're expecting 2011 to be higher than 2010.
We avoided material impairments, we achieved positive lease roll over every year and in fact every quarter, maintained strong and steady occupancy, maintained a conservative balance sheet with no significant equity delusion, we've paid an increasing all cash dividend on our common shares.  There are few, if any, public real estate companies that can match that performance over the prior three years.
Turning now to our results, let's start with the quarter. Same-store property operating income came in at a positive 0.8% including redevelopments and positive 1.1% excluding redevelopments for the quarter. This was despite the negative impact we've discussed before from the loss of the Home Depot lease termination fee in Flourtown in Philly. The drivers of this growth were continued steady occupancy and an increase in minimum rent by 3.8%, driven by the consistency of our operating portfolio and supported by redevelopment impacts of properties like Hampden Lane in Bethesda and Linden Square.
The full impact of this increase in minimum rent doesn't show up in the rental income line because 'twas offset by recoveries, which were down 11% for the quarter. Largely driven by significantly lower snow removal cost in this year's fourth quarter compared to 2009
Along the operating line, we saw decreases in interest expense as we held significant cash balances at the end of 2009 before repaying the last of our term loan in the third quarter of 2010. 
G&A increased $1.3 million through increases in acquisition, development and personnel costs. All in, FFO per share clips the dollar mark for the first time ever at $1.1 for the quarter. 
Moving now to the full year 2010. As Don mentioned, we produced record topline revenue in 2010 on flat 93.2% year-over-year occupancy. 
Once again, buoyed by positive full year lease roll overs of 8%. Same-store property operating income grew 2.3% including redevelopment, and 2.1% excluding redevelopment. 
Continued growth in property operating income, G&A control and balance sheet management, not just not now, but throughout the past several years, contributed to our record FFO of $239 million or $3.88 per share, and that bulk fee considering the operating environment over that period.
Another item to note in our 2010 financials. You may have seen in our disclosure that we received a final judgment relating to our appeal of 350 Winchester litigation at Santana Row. We're disappointed in losing our appeal with the associated $16.2 million payment on the matter. However, the full amount have been accrued in '09, there is no significant new earnings impact related to this final roll in fourth quarter results, we do not expect any related earnings towards this in 2011.
You need to expand and redevelopment disclosure in the 8-K. Our goal is to provide more detail on value creation opportunities we'll be pursuing over the next several years. Including that, were increased discussion of two of our larger projects, Assembly Row and Mid-Pike. 
Last quarter, Don gave an update on Assembly Row in a recent agreement with AvalonBay. And at that time, we are still working through final approvals for our new Orange Line T station at the site. . 
Last week, we announced the MBTA had unanimously voted in support of a memorandum of understanding with Federal Realty for the construction of the T station.
This marks a big step forward with respect to the T-Stop at Assembly Row becoming our value. Phase one of Assembly Row, which should be done in partnership with AvalonBay, will include three buildings, totaling 419 residential units, plus 280,000 square feet of retail, all in addition to the existing 337,000 square-foot power center at The Assembly Square marketplace.
AvalonBay will build the two residential buildings with 110,000 square feet of retail on the ground form. Buy back the retail shells, similar to what we did at Rockville Town Square. 
Federal will build the remaining 180,000 square foot retail building. We began actively leasing the project with the opening of our marketing center late last year, and are already seeing interest from users. Total Phase One costs are expected to be about $100 million to $125 million range.
In North Bethesda, our overall sketch plans for the redevelopment of Mid-Pike Plaza was approved on January 20, allowing us to move forward on submitting a plan for that project's first phase in April, with the anticipated approval later this year. With all approvals in place, we may be able to begin construction in mid-2012, on the approximately $200 million first phase to include 240,000 square feet of retail and office space, and approximately 400 residential units and appropriate parking.
The phasing of the project means the remainder of the center will be open and operating during construction, which allow us to continue receiving a steady stream of income through stabilization of the first phase.
Future phases of the project will be timed according to the success of the first phase, but the total project is anticipated to include over 3 million square feet of Commercial Real Estate with filled out over the next 10 to 15 years.
Moving on to guidance. We're leaving our 2011 FFO per share guidance of $3.95 to $4.02 unchanged. Obviously, the news out of Borders this morning with $3 million or $0.05 per share of contribution makes it more difficult for us. And as a result, we'd certainly guided to the lower end of the range.
Having said that, it's only February and there are many positives or negatives that can happen throughout the year. We certainly believe any hit in the near term will be longer-term opportunity to create value going forward, as Don said. 
Operator, we will now turn the call over for your question.

componenttext: Just firstly, in terms of acquisitions and if we look at the sought acquisition, obviously, a quality asset with redevelopment potential. And given that pricing on below core assets without as much redevelopment opportunities getting quite expensive, should we set of think about acquisitions that you're looking at over 2011 and '12 as being more larger scale-redevelopment place?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Quentin, I'm going to ask Jeff to kind of talk a little bit more about this. But let me give you a point of view on this. It is just crazy to pay some of the numbers that are being required on very flat, very hopefully stable, basic core assets with
componenttext: Well, Quentin, I'm going to ask Jeff to kind of talk a little bit more about this. But let me give you a point of view on this. It is just crazy to pay some of the numbers that are being required on very flat, very hopefully stable, basic core assets without really any potential to add value to them. We all know what our cost capital is and it's just a lot of the stuff we're seeing won't allow that to happen. When you talk about the opportunity to put six to seven acres together and effectively carry it, the sixth is going in and then stabilize the seventh, with a bunch of acreage left, that looks attractive to us. That we can see it pass the value creation. So we got to be able to see that path. Now whether it's on the form of larger properties, which we always like, because I do believe you can do a lot more -- a lot more comes up down the road when you've got the acreage there, or whether it is in the few of the places where you do have some undervalued acres or acreage in terms of rent that are being pay, either one that works for us. But yes, I think it's reasonable to assume that you should expect to see bigger type of assets generally on the acquisition side for us because there's got to be a way to create value at it for us to do with.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, you're absolutely right. If there's an asset today that comes to the market that's institutional quality and one of the better trade areas on the East and West Coast, that's relatively easy to underwrite, that doesn't have any existin
componenttext: Just to add to that, you're absolutely right. If there's an asset today that comes to the market that's institutional quality and one of the better trade areas on the East and West Coast, that's relatively easy to underwrite, that doesn't have any existing debt attached to it, the pricing is spectacular. We're back down into the cap rate range of significantly below six. And with reasonable assumptions going forward, IRR is, in some cases, are below even 7% or maybe, slightly above 7%. So clearly, chasing those assets and paying those prices when they're so value-added proposition does really makes no sense. So we're focused on things where we think we can generate returns that exceed our longer-term cost of capital. Like Don said, those are generally going to be bigger deals.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I guess, with IRRs, as well as that for the stabilized assets that you sort of looking at selling any quality assets that don't have this higher growth profile?
componenttext: And I guess, with IRRs, as well as that for the stabilized assets that you sort of looking at selling any quality assets that don't have this higher growth profile?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we always consider that, particularly when we're doing an all-cash acquisition. But it's a matter of balance for us because a lot of our assets, we've owned for a long time, we have added a lot of value to, have a very low tax basis. And we won't do
componenttext: Well, we always consider that, particularly when we're doing an all-cash acquisition. But it's a matter of balance for us because a lot of our assets, we've owned for a long time, we have added a lot of value to, have a very low tax basis. And we won't do anything that would create a capital gain tax situation. And then of course we balance that with earnings as well but we do constantly look at the portfolio and when we have the opportunity to through a cash acquisition, do a Verse 1031 exchange, we definitely consider that.

componenttext: Yes, we've got, Chris, after this in a second. We've got four. We've got one at Santana Row in the flagship position. We'll have lots of opportunities to read 10 in that space. That in some ways is the toughest for us because it's in such an important part space at Santana that it needs to be the right tenant to do that. It's interesting for me, that's a really interesting one because Borders hasn't been adding to that property for a long time now. And it sits in a very important part of the project yet the project continues to get better. So this is a real opportunity for us at Santana to be able to kind of re-merchandise that with the 2011, '12, '13 type of tenant that will be great for the future. Friendship Center, down Maryland, great thought. In fact, Chris, I know we have a bunch of things working on that spot already. Old Town Center in Los Gatos, California, that has to be re-done in Wynnewood on the main line and outside of Philadelphia. So if you think about those four locations, we're going to have our transfers, that's for sure at.

componenttext: You know what? Stronger in the better properties and flatter in the B's and C's and really, nothing new from that prospective. Where I feel pretty good is kind of looking hard at the land we already own throughout this portfolio. And that's at existing shopping centers, as well as the big projects in Mid-Pike, which really should be a good one and Assembly. So when I look at those things, I do see with no land costs because we own those properties already. The ability to put money to work at general enhancing of values where I am most optimistic when it comes to the day in and day out leasing, it's a real mixed bag, man. There is strong demand and we are seeing some ability to get better rents in key spots at great properties. But it's tough in the average and even in the above average stuff. So there's a real dichotomy there.

And the others are operating at a different level at a new normal. They have been able to find some of the financing that they haven't been able to. To the extent they're new. And things have settled pretty good. That's different, I'll tell you in a couple of properties we still see in Florida, it's still a bloodbath from what we see in terms of the small shop there. It's a completely different world than it is outside of Washington D.C. At Santana and the Northern California for us, a very strong recovery, vis-Ã -vis where they were. It's very market dependent and within the market, very shopping center dependent.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Since you mentioned Florida, I'm curious if you could talk a moment about how you think the composition of your returns like long term in Florida, maybe vis-a-vis your existing assets? Because I think in the mid-Atlantic, in Northeast California, people t
componenttext: Since you mentioned Florida, I'm curious if you could talk a moment about how you think the composition of your returns like long term in Florida, maybe vis-a-vis your existing assets? Because I think in the mid-Atlantic, in Northeast California, people think of Federal's existing portfolios being through affluent, undersupplied submarkets that are maybe more about NAV growth than current cash flow yield? Is the opportunity in Florida more about achieving higher current income yields than it is long-term NAV growth?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's not. It is long term NAV growth which is really what is very, very important to us. Now the issue, it's tough for us to sit back and say well, this is how it works in Florida because we really don't have the sample size to make any determination. We'
componenttext: It's not. It is long term NAV growth which is really what is very, very important to us. Now the issue, it's tough for us to sit back and say well, this is how it works in Florida because we really don't have the sample size to make any determination. We're talking about two assess that we've had during the worst time in the history of Florida there. And now a new acquisition that I can tell you, or Chris can certainly tell you, the demand since we've taken it over looks extremely encouraging. So I'd like to tell you more. Our objective is always to buy real estate that will be more down the road than less. And it's not about spread investing in any of the markets that we're in. So whether we're successful or not in finding the right properties and in being able to redevelop an asset. That's in the story that will be evident over time. But that's what we're trying to suggest, it's the same amount.

componenttextpreview: Don is up in Boston, he's not available on the call today. But I think I can speak for him since we just had this conversation. A couple of really interesting things going on. Today, you know Assembly Square, it is absolutely not an office market today, i
componenttext: Don is up in Boston, he's not available on the call today. But I think I can speak for him since we just had this conversation. A couple of really interesting things going on. Today, you know Assembly Square, it is absolutely not an office market today, it's just not. We get going on this first phase, which will not be a robust first phase, wherever it will be, somewhere between $6 million and $7 million to kind of get started there, I think, still working on those pieces. But it's all about creating a place. That plus T plus some of the other stuff that's going on, that I can't just talk about yet, will clearly make it a more attractive office environment. I will tell you there is a tenant up in Boston, it was a large tenant up in Boston, I think you know about it, that was considering our site. And wound up after a lot of due diligence choosing another that they have been far down the road on. But frankly, we left there very encouraged because it was validating that a large office player would look and considered a vision that we see for Assembly. So in talking with our brokers between that look that, that tenant made and some other things that was going there, I'm optimistic that it's not certainly not next year or the year after in terms of being able to get the right office tenant there. But down the road, 54 acres there and we'll be building a first phase that takes up a small piece of that. There is absolutely opportunity or we wouldn't be doing the first phase.

But I think it's still early in that recovery process to be able to say, oh and therefore, we'll do five new deals with this guy or three new deals with that guy to be able to push. Not yet, too early.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the hard part of your question to answer is the timing. But what we've got when we got Tower was a very well-located regional piece of land at the intersection of a busy surface street on a freeway. That have been neglected or certainly not f
componenttext: Yes, I think the hard part of your question to answer is the timing. But what we've got when we got Tower was a very well-located regional piece of land at the intersection of a busy surface street on a freeway. That have been neglected or certainly not focused on intensely over the last several years. Along with the ability to add about 80,000 square feet of GLA to the site. So there's a couple of things that we can do right away. One is getting in focus on the operations of the center, kind of the nuts and bolts and tidy things up a bit. There is  a plan to improve the existing physical plant which we think will go a long way towards driving NOI growth going forward. And then there's also the ability to add additional GLA, the question you asked is appropriate, and that's going to be dependent upon tenant demand, obviously. But there's definitely ability to do somethings there immediately and in the kind of medium term, if you will. That are going to really drive NOI growth. We are very happy with the acquisition.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: Jeff, what's your pipeline with NAREIT Right now?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's pretty -- we're busy. There a lot of stuff that we're working on right now that's very interesting. But all of it, again, because it's not stabilized and institutional. Is it done to write sub-7 IRRs. All that's got a lot of moving parts. A lot
componenttext: Yes, it's pretty -- we're busy. There a lot of stuff that we're working on right now that's very interesting. But all of it, again, because it's not stabilized and institutional. Is it done to write sub-7 IRRs. All that's got a lot of moving parts. A lot of things that aren't in our control. So again, its difficult to be too predictive about what we're going to get done and when and how much. But we've got a lot of interesting things going on right now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nate, let me tell you one other thing you didn't asked about Tower Shops that I wanted to bring up with you. One of the reasons we made that acquisition or we were in a position to make that acquisition, is because we are in a position to absorb the outst
componenttext: Nate, let me tell you one other thing you didn't asked about Tower Shops that I wanted to bring up with you. One of the reasons we made that acquisition or we were in a position to make that acquisition, is because we are in a position to absorb the outstanding debt on a number of these shopping centers. In a lot of cases, that debt is above market. That's the case at Tower. What I think our due diligence and our process kind of laid out though was we've got the ability to refinance that debt. I'm not sure if you knew that frankly, I'm looking at that property. And so the ability to buy it at $68 million, which if it didn't have above market data, that property would have gotten a lot higher than that. And so with the ability to buy at that price and then to refinance out of the above market debt and something more in line with Federal's cost of capital or cost of debt capital is really value-additive. So add that to conversation at Tower.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't expect it will roll down in total. These boxes are all on average, just looking at here, I don't have a full average but somewhere around $20 in there, $20 to $21 of these certainly, that's not the case, it's actually less than that. That's right,
componenttext: I don't expect it will roll down in total. These boxes are all on average, just looking at here, I don't have a full average but somewhere around $20 in there, $20 to $21 of these certainly, that's not the case, it's actually less than that. That's right, $20, $21. So when you think about the location that just went through before Santana and Chevy Chase and Los Gatos and the mainline in Philadelphia, we're going to get those rents from there and downtime this year so it's going to hurt us from an earnings perspective this year. But the key thing that you're asking is those shopping centers are not going to be worth less because Borders is going away. Because we'll be able to re-lease them up for at or better than those rents. And it's a real important distinction.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: It was $41 million at about 6.5% and the maturity date on the loan is on 2015. And like Don mentioned what we found when we got into the deal I really don't think anybody knew this. Quite frankly, when the property was put on the market, because it wasn't disclosed in the OEM. When we got into the deal, we obviously read the loan documents and some of the provisions of the loan documents wants a stand off in June of this year. So we're pretty happy to find that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think the hit in the first quarter would be Borders, frankly but I don't expect a very strong first quarter. But it really won't be weather-oriented, certainly not more than last year. And this year, what happened with was that East Coast was much m
componenttext: No, I think the hit in the first quarter would be Borders, frankly but I don't expect a very strong first quarter. But it really won't be weather-oriented, certainly not more than last year. And this year, what happened with was that East Coast was much more normal and that is storms came in, they made a left Washington DC and headed up to Boston, New York and last year, they all came through Washington. So we think Mid-Atlantic hit in there. So it won't be weather. But as I said, for other reasons, first quarter is quite soft.

It's non-recurring and once again, we think that 2011 we're going to get back down to a normalized level of about $2 million, $2.5 million as opposed to the $7 million that we did in 2010.

componenttextpreview: That's what we're thinking. And that's the deal. Offline we could do probably a little bit better with you. But the bottom line is in any 12 month period of time, when you look at the 12 month period of time of where we think we're going to be, 2011 is no
componenttext: That's what we're thinking. And that's the deal. Offline we could do probably a little bit better with you. But the bottom line is in any 12 month period of time, when you look at the 12 month period of time of where we think we're going to be, 2011 is not going to be a strong growth from an FFO perspective. There'll be some but it's not going to be a strong growth here for the reasons we enumerated. The value creation stuff that we're working on won't benefit '11 yet. I think it's wonderful for the future. The acquisitions so far won't benefit '11, I think it's wonderful for the future. The absence of the termination fees from '10 and '09 won't be there this year and we're certainly going to have an issue at least with Borders and maybe a little bit of Barnes in '11. So when you put all that together, I think it's amazing, frankly, that you'll see some growth in '11 versus '10, versus '09 versus '08. And I know you're used to maybe looking at some other companies that have the absence of impairments and things like that the show more growth, if you will, although I think it's more accounting growth than real growth.

componenttext: Let me put it to you this way. In my initial remarks, I had written in there that we are getting, we're feeling more confident about being able to take more down on Newbury Street. headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Year End 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Year End 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you, and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's fourth quarter and year end 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Chris Weilminster and
componenttext:
Great, thank you, and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's fourth quarter and year end 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Chris Weilminster and Jeff Berkes. 
In addition to our fourth quarter and year end 2010 supplemental disclosure package, we also filed our 10-K yesterday. Those documents provide you with a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trustâs 2010 operating and financial performance and both are currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations.
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of fourth quarter and year end 2010 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. In trying to decide how to talk about 2010 and then set expectations for 2011 with you all today, it's helpful for me to step back a bit and look top-down.I jotted down a list of some of the things we got done t
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. In trying to decide how to talk about 2010 and then set expectations for 2011 with you all today, it's helpful for me to step back a bit and look top-down.
I jotted down a list of some of the things we got done this year and on reflection before I read them to you. But here's what happened.
In this economy, we grew top line revenue 2.5% to a record $543 million. We grew same store, same-center property operating income 2.1% to a record $350 million.
We grew FFO per share 2.6% to a record $388 million, with no easy prior period comparable. We grew 2010 fourth quarter FFO to $1.01 per share, first time any quarter to ever hit a $1. We negotiated 312 new and renewal releases at positive leasing spreads, 8% cash, 18% straight line.
Maintained occupancy levels year-over-year at 93.2%. We made our first investments on Newbury Street, and theyâre performing above our underwriting.
We accretively bought out the land on the Pentagon Row and Bethesda Row. We delivered our hand in lane and Bethesda project on time, on budget, fully leased. We increased our footprint at Escondido in San Diego, at Huntington in Long Island and recently added our third property in Florida just outside of Fort Lauderdale.
We completed and leased up most of our office building in Santana, we broke ground on our 108-unit residential building there and we've accelerated our plans to build the next one. 
We signed our deal with AvalonBay at Assembly Square. We negotiated a deal on T-Stop funding which is recently unanimously approved by the MBTA. We hope to break ground on this project late 2011 or early 2012.
The overall White Flint sector plan and our Mid-Pike masting [ph] plan was approved, making way for first phase construction at Mid-Pike which is tentatively planned to begin in 2012. And we did increase our dividend rate on common shares for the 43rd year in a row.
So 2010 was a very good year for us, and 2011 should be too, even though we'll be hit pretty badly in the short-term by the Borders bankruptcy, along with some of the other non-recurring lease termination fees that we'll talk about.
But we've got a lot done in 2010, and while we didn't deploy as much capital as we would have liked to big acquisitions, we created a lot of value in what we did do and we clearly saw a pick up on desirable products as the year progressed.
We were able to close on our Tower Shops in Florida last month and expect a more active 2011 from that perspective. Though at the moment, I'd say I'm more optimistic even about the future value creation through redevelopment that we've identified.
I went back and looked at the forward-looking comments I made on this call back in August and then again, in November, concerning our view of the major markets do business in, as well as the leasing and operating environment. And I've got to say, it all still applies and is generally moving in the right direction. Retailers want to get deals done in virtually all the markets we do business in but with a tough cost-conscious mentality that's certainly here to stay.
Basically itâs harder for us to create a more valuable company simply by raising rents. Having said that, Washington D.C. remains the steadiest and the strongest of our markets with California improving the fastest, particularly at Santana Row and Third Street Promenade in Santa Monica. Lots more value for us to add at both of those California properties.
I mentioned Borders a minute ago. Let me put a finer point on that. The troubles at Borders Books will hurt us in 2011, no doubt. We have four Borders locations paying a total of $3 million in rent and extras, about $0.05 a share, and they stopped paying rent in February. 
Certainly, that income stream is at risk in the short run. But when you think about it in the longer-term, Borders hasn't really been an effective draw to the shopping centers that they're in for a number of years now. I can't imagine that's going to change anytime soon, no matter how their situation gets resolved.
So if you're us, you can understand why we'd be anxious to work through these deals as quickly as possible so that we can release those prime locations to healthier tenants. An intense effort to uncover additional value creative opportunities throughout the portfolio has us beefing up on our leasing and redevelopment staff. Additional residential opportunities on our existing land look very possible at places like Congressional Plaza, like Bethesda, like Shirlington, like Barracks Road and others, not to mention our large developments at Mid-Pike and Assembly and still more to come at Santana Row. Lots of optimism around here on that potential.
In summary, despite what remains a very challenging economic environment, it is an improving one. And our path to future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. That value will be led by retail and non-retail redevelopment and re-tenanting opportunities, along with new raw material in the form of some pretty good acquisitions that we're making progress on. Tower Shops in Davie, Florida is a good start.
That's all I got for my prepared remarks this morning. Let me now turn it over to Andy, and I look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Now I really echo Don's sentiments, and I continue to be impressed by how solid our performance has been over the past three years of this [Audio Gap] and how we're positioned for the future.Think about this. 200
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Now I really echo Don's sentiments, and I continue to be impressed by how solid our performance has been over the past three years of this [Audio Gap] and how we're positioned for the future.
Think about this. 2008 property operating income was higher than 2007. 2009 was higher than 2008, 2010 was higher than 2009. We're expecting 2011 to be higher than 2010.
We avoided material impairments. We achieved positive lease roll over every year and, in fact, every quarter, maintained strong and steady occupancy, we maintained a conservative balance sheet with no significant equity dilution, and we've paid an increasing all cash dividend on our common shares.  There are few, if any, public real estate companies that can match that performance over the prior three years.
Turning now to our results, let's start with the quarter. Same-store property operating income came in at a positive 0.8% including redevelopments and positive 1.1% excluding redevelopments for the quarter. This was despite the negative impact we've discussed before from the loss of the Home Depot lease termination fee in Flourtown in Philly. The drivers of this growth were continued steady occupancy and an increase in minimum rent by 3.8%, driven by the consistency of our operating portfolio and supported by redevelopment impacts of properties like Hampden Lane in Bethesda and Linden Square.
The full impact of this increase in minimum rent doesn't show up in the rental income line because it was offset by recoveries, which were down 11% for the quarter. Largely driven by significantly lower snow removal costs in this year's fourth quarter compared to 2009.
Below the operating line, we saw decreases in interest expense as we held significant cash balances at the end of 2009 before repaying the last of our term loan in the third quarter of 2010. 
G&A increased $1.3 million through increases in acquisition, development and personnel costs. All in, FFO per share eclipsed the dollar mark for the first time ever at $1.01 for the quarter. 
Turning now to the full year 2010. As Don mentioned, we produced record top line revenue in 2010 on flat 93.2% year-over-year occupancy, once again, buoyed by positive full year lease roll overs of 8%. Same-store property operating income grew 2.3% including redevelopment and 2.1% excluding redevelopment. 
Continued growth in property operating income, G&A control and balance sheet management, not just not now, but throughout the past several years, contributed to our record FFO of $239 million or $3.88 per share, an admirable feat considering the operating environment over that period.
One other item to note in our 2010 financials. You may have seen in our disclosure that we received a final judgment relating to our appeal of 350 Winchester litigation at Santana Row. We're disappointed in losing our appeal and the associated $16.2 million payment on the matter. However, the full amount had been accrued in '09, there was no significant new earnings impact related to this final ruling in fourth quarter results. We do not expect any related earnings charges in 2011.
I hope that you saw our expanded redevelopment disclosure in the 8-K. Our goal is to provide more detail on value creation opportunities we'll be pursuing over the next several years. Including that were increased discussions of two of our larger projects, Assembly Row and Mid-Pike. 
Last quarter, Don gave an update on Assembly Row in a recent agreement with AvalonBay. And at that time, we were still working through final approvals for our new Orange Line T station at the site. Last week, we announced the MBTA had unanimously voted in support of a memorandum of understanding with Federal Realty for the construction of the T station.
This marks a big step forward with respect to the T-Stop at Assembly Row becoming a reality. Phase one of Assembly Row, which will be done in partnership with AvalonBay, will include three buildings, totaling 419 residential units, plus 280,000 square feet of retail, all in addition to the existing 337,000 square-foot power center at The Assembly Square marketplace.
AvalonBay will build the two residential buildings with 110,000 square feet of retail on the ground floor. And weâll buy back the retail shells [ph], similar to what we did at Rockville Town Square. 
Federal will build the remaining 180,000 square foot retail building. We began actively leasing the project with the opening of our marketing center late last year, and are already seeing interest from retail users. Total Phase One costs are expected to be in the $100 million to $125 million range.
In North Bethesda, our overall sketch plan for the redevelopment of Mid-Pike Plaza was approved on January 20, allowing us to move forward on submitting a plan for that project's first phase in April, with the anticipated approval later this year. With all approvals in place, we may be able to begin construction in mid-2012, on the approximately $200 million first phase to include 230,000 square feet of retail and office space and approximately 400 residential units and appropriate parking.
The phasing of the project means the remainder of the center will be open and operating during construction, which will allow us to continue receiving a steady stream of income through stabilization of the first phase.
Future phases of the project will be timed according to the success of the first phase, but the total project is anticipated to include over 3 million square feet of Commercial Real Estate with filled out over the next 10 to 15 years.
Moving on to guidance. We're leaving our 2011 FFO per share guidance of $3.95 to $4.02 unchanged. Obviously, the news out of Borders this morning with $3 million or $0.05 per share of contribution makes it more difficult for us. And as a result, we'd certainly guide you to the lower end of the range.
Having said that, it's only February, and there are many positives or negatives that can happen throughout the year. We certainly believe any hit in the near term will be longer-term opportunity to create value going forward, as Don said. 
Operator, we will now turn the call over to your questions.
