headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just firstly, in terms of acquisitions and if we look at the Florida acquisition, that was, obviously, a quality asset with redevelopment potential. And given that pricing on A-grade stabilized or core assets without as much redevelopment opportunity is g
componenttext: Just firstly, in terms of acquisitions and if we look at the Florida acquisition, that was, obviously, a quality asset with redevelopment potential. And given that pricing on A-grade stabilized or core assets without as much redevelopment opportunity is getting quite expensive, should we set of think about acquisitions that you're looking at over 2011 and '12 as being more larger scale-redevelopment plays?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Quentin, I'm going to ask Jeff to kind of talk a little bit more about this. But let me give you a point of view on this. It is just crazy to pay some of the numbers that are being required on very flat, very hopefully stable, basic core assets with
componenttext: Well, Quentin, I'm going to ask Jeff to kind of talk a little bit more about this. But let me give you a point of view on this. It is just crazy to pay some of the numbers that are being required on very flat, very hopefully stable, basic core assets without really any potential to add value to them. We all know what our cost to capital is, and it's just a lot of the stuff we're seeing won't allow that to happen. When you talk about the opportunity to put 67 acres together and effectively carry it at the sixes going in and then stabilize in the sevens, with a bunch of acreage left, that looks attractive to us. That we can see a path to value creation. So we got to be able to see that path. Now whether it's in the form of larger properties, which we always like, because I do believe you can do a lot more -- a lot more comes up down the road when you've got the acreage there, or whether it is in a few of the places where you do have some undervalued acres or anchors in terms of rents that are being pay, either one works for us. But yes, I think it's reasonable to assume that you should expect to see bigger type of assets generally on the acquisition side for us because there's got to be a way to create value at it for us to do it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Iâd add to that, you're absolutely right. If there's an asset today that comes to the market that's institutional quality and one of the better trade areas on the East and West Coast that's relatively easy to underwrite, that doesn't have any existing d
componenttext: Iâd add to that, you're absolutely right. If there's an asset today that comes to the market that's institutional quality and one of the better trade areas on the East and West Coast that's relatively easy to underwrite, that doesn't have any existing debt attached to it, the pricing is spectacular. We're back down into the cap rate range of significantly below six. And with reasonable assumptions going forward, the IRRs, in some cases, are below even 7% or maybe, slightly above 7%. So clearly, chasing those assets and paying those prices when thereâs no value-add proposition to us really makes no sense. So we're focused on things where we think we can generate returns that exceed our long-term cost of capital. Like Don said, those are generally going to be bigger deals.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I guess, with IRRs, as low as that for the stabilized assets, are you sort of looking at selling any quality assets that don't have as high a growth profile?
componenttext: And I guess, with IRRs, as low as that for the stabilized assets, are you sort of looking at selling any quality assets that don't have as high a growth profile?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we always consider that, particularly when we're doing an all-cash acquisition. But it's a matter of balance for us because a lot of our assets, we've owned for a long time, we have added a lot of value to, they have very low tax bases. And we won't
componenttext: Well, we always consider that, particularly when we're doing an all-cash acquisition. But it's a matter of balance for us because a lot of our assets, we've owned for a long time, we have added a lot of value to, they have very low tax bases. And we won't do anything that would create a capital gain tax situation. And then of course we balance that with earnings as well but we do constantly look at the portfolio and when we have the opportunity to through a cash acquisition, do a reverse 1031 exchange, we definitely consider that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: And then just lastly, Don sort of touched on the Borders Chapter 11 filing, and I think you got the full Borders in the portfolio. Can you set of talk through what some of the -- assuming those leases get rejected what some of the re-tenanting opportunities might be?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got, Chris, after this in a second. We've got four. We've got one at Santana Row in the flagship position. We'll have lots of opportunities to re-tenant that space. That in some ways is the toughest for us because it's in such an important spac
componenttext: Yes, we've got, Chris, after this in a second. We've got four. We've got one at Santana Row in the flagship position. We'll have lots of opportunities to re-tenant that space. That in some ways is the toughest for us because it's in such an important space at Santana that it needs to be the right tenant to do that. It's interesting to me, that's a really interesting one because Borders hasn't been adding to that property for a long time now. And it sits in a very important part of the project, yet the project continues to get better. So this is a real opportunity for us at Santana to be able to re-tenant, re-merchandise that with a 2011, '12, '13 type of tenant that will be great for the future. Friendship Center, down in Chevy Chase, Maryland, great spot. In fact, Chris, I know we have a bunch of things working on that spot already. Old Town Center in Los Gatos, California, that has to be re-done, and Wynnewood on the main line outside of Philadelphia. So if you think about those four locations, we're going to have our transfers [ph], that's for sure.

componenttext: It is, and that's a big worry for me. Not so much or as much about the tenantâs ability to survive, but just like Bed Bath and Beyond without Linens and just like Best Buy without Circuit City, Barnes without Borders is in a better negotiating position. And so I kind of worry about how that's all going to play out. Certainly, a very well-run company and doing things that should allow them to be better prepared for the new economy. But we've got work to do to make sure that we're protecting our properties there. I don't know how that will turn out, we'll see over the next couple of years.

componenttext: And Don, you mentioned sort of optimism broadly if the cycle turns a bit, but where do you see leasing spreads trending over the next 12 months?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: You know what? Stronger in the better properties and flatter in the Bs and Cs and really, nothing new from that prospective. Where I feel pretty good is kind of looking hard at the land we already own throughout this portfolio. And that's at existing shop
componenttext: You know what? Stronger in the better properties and flatter in the Bs and Cs and really, nothing new from that prospective. Where I feel pretty good is kind of looking hard at the land we already own throughout this portfolio. And that's at existing shopping centers, as well as the big projects in Mid-Pike, which really should be a good one, and Assembly. So when I look at those things, I do see, with low land costs because we own those properties already, the ability to put money to work at shareholder enhancing of values is where I am most optimistic when it comes to the day in and day out leasing, it's a real mixed bag, man. There is strong demand, and we are seeing some ability to get better rents in key spots at great properties. But it's tough in the average and even in slightly above average stuff. So there's a real dichotomy there.

But I've got to say, that will hit us, but it's February and good things and bad things will happen for the rest of the year. So we'll see where we turn out.

componenttext: Yes, and very, very market-focused here. When you look at the Washington area and the small shop ability to -- first of all, ability to absorb lower sales levels over the past couple of years, the ones that canât are kind of gone. And the others are operating at a different level, at a new normal. They have been able to find some of the financing that they haven't been able to, to the extent they needed. And things have settled pretty good. Now that's different, I'll tell you in a couple of properties we still see in Florida, it's still a bloodbath from what we see in terms of the small shop there. It's a completely different world than it is outside of Washington D.C. At Santana and the Northern California for us, a very strong recovery, vis-Ã -vis where they were. It's very market dependent and within the market, very shopping center dependent.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Since you mentioned Florida, I'm curious if you could talk a moment about how you think the composition of your returns like long term in Florida, maybe vis- Ã  -vis your existing assets? Because I think in the mid-Atlantic, in Northeast California, peopl
componenttext: Since you mentioned Florida, I'm curious if you could talk a moment about how you think the composition of your returns like long term in Florida, maybe vis- Ã  -vis your existing assets? Because I think in the mid-Atlantic, in Northeast California, people think of Federal's existing portfolios being through affluent, undersupplied submarkets that are maybe more about NAV growth than current cash flow yield? Is the opportunity in Florida more about achieving higher current income yields than it is long-term NAV growth?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's not. It is long term NAV growth, which is really what is very, very important to us. Now the issue, it's tough for us to sit back and say, well, this is how it works in Florida because we really don't have the sample size to make any determination. W
componenttext: It's not. It is long term NAV growth, which is really what is very, very important to us. Now the issue, it's tough for us to sit back and say, well, this is how it works in Florida because we really don't have the sample size to make any determination. We're talking about two assets that we've had during the worst time in the history of Florida there. And now a new acquisition that I can tell you, or Chris can certainly tell you, the demand since we've taken it over looks extremely encouraging. So I'd like to tell you more. Our objective is always to buy real estate that will be worth more down the road than less. And it's not about spread investing in any of the markets that we're in. So whether we're successful or not in buying the right properties and in being able to redevelop that, develop them, that's another story that will be evident over time. But that's what we're trying to do, Jeff. It's the same MO.

componenttext: Don is up in Boston, he's not available on the call today. But I think I can speak for him since we just had this conversation. A couple of really interesting things going on. Today, you know Assembly Square, it is absolutely not an office market today. It's just not. We get going on this first phase, which will not be a robust first phase, wherever it will be, somewhere between $6 million and $7 million to kind of get started there, I think, still working on those pieces. But it's all about creating a place. That plus a T plus some of the other stuff that's going on, that I can't just talk about yet, will clearly make it a more attractive office environment. I will tell you there is a tenant up in Boston, it was a large tenant up in Boston, I think you know about it, that was considering our site and wound up after a lot of due diligence choosing another that they had been far down the road on. But frankly, we left there very encouraged because it was validating that a large office player would look and consider the vision that we see for Assembly. So in talking with our brokers between that look that, that tenant made and some other things that weâve got going there, I'm optimistic that it's not certainly not next year or the year after in terms of being able to get the right office tenant there. But down the road, 54 acres there and we'll be building a first phase that takes up a small piece of that. There is absolutely opportunity or we wouldn't be doing the first phase.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the hard part of your question to answer, Nate, is the timing. But what we got when we got Tower was a very well-located regional piece of land at the intersection of a busy surface street and a freeway that had been neglected or certainly no
componenttext: Yes, I think the hard part of your question to answer, Nate, is the timing. But what we got when we got Tower was a very well-located regional piece of land at the intersection of a busy surface street and a freeway that had been neglected or certainly not focused on intently over the last several years along with the ability to add about 80,000 square feet of GLA to the site. So there's a couple of things that we can do right away. One is getting in focus on the operations of the center, kind of the nuts and bolts and tidy things up a bit. There is a plan to improve the existing physical plant which we think will go a long way towards driving NOI growth going forward. And then there also is the ability to add additional GLA, the question you asked is appropriate, when, and that's going to be dependent upon tenant demand, obviously. But there's definitely the ability to do some things there immediately and in the kind of medium term, if you will, that are going to really drive NOI growth. Weâre very happy with the acquisition.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nate, let me tell you one other thing you didn't ask about Tower Shops that I wanted to bring up with you. One of the reasons we made that acquisition or we were in a position to make that acquisition is because we are in a position to absorb the outstand
componenttext: Nate, let me tell you one other thing you didn't ask about Tower Shops that I wanted to bring up with you. One of the reasons we made that acquisition or we were in a position to make that acquisition is because we are in a position to absorb the outstanding debt on a number of these shopping centers. In a lot of cases, that debt is above market. That's the case at Tower. What I think our due diligence and our process kind of laid out though was we've got the ability to refinance that debt. I'm not sure everybody knew that, frankly, in looking at that property. And so the ability to buy it at $68 million, which if it didn't have above market data, that property would have gone a lot higher than that. And so with the ability to buy at that price and then to refinance out of the above market debt and something more in line with Federal's cost of capital or cost of debt capital is really value-additive. So let me add that to the conversation about Tower.

componenttext: It was $41 million at about 6.5% and the maturity date on the loan is on 2015. When we got into the deal, we obviously read the loan documents and found a provision in the loan documents that lets us pay the loan off in June of this year. So we were pretty happy to find that.

componenttext: No, I think the hit in the first quarter will be Borders, frankly so I don't expect a very strong first quarter. componenttext: That's what we're thinking. And that's the deal. Offline, we could do probably a little bit better with you. headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Bird
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Jeff Berkes and Chris Weilminster. These an
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Andy Blocher, Jeff Berkes and Chris Weilminster. These and other members of our management team are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Our first quarter 2011 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the trust's operating and financial performance. The document is currently available on our website. Federal Realty now in Twitter, and you can follow us for news and updates with our Twitter handle Federal Realty.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected of future events on our results. although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected on such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements and we can give you no assurance that expectations would be attained.
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but not are limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks in costs of construction. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report found on Form 10-K and our other financial documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
now turn the call over to Don Wood, to begin our discussion on first quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quarter, we took about $0.05 a share hit for an early extinguishment of debt charge, but we also booked about $0.05 per share benefit from the end of the large lease termination fees from Home Depot. Those 2 transactions more or less were offset last year. And so with or without them, we'd still reporting a 5% increase this quarter.
Now let's did into the quarter a bit, 91 leases executed for 340,000 space and new average rents of $30.52, 11% higher than the $27.55 per foot that they replaced, Michael's replacing Foot Locker at Shopping Center and LA Fitness replacing Toys R Us at Shopping Center along with a couple of bank renewals led the increase. 
There are certainly still deals that we're making where rental rates are moving down. And in my opinion, there will continue to be deals like that for the foreseeable future, but those deals are making up a smaller and smaller percentage. For example in this first quarter, of the 91 comparable leases signed, 19 of them rolled rent down. Thus, 21% of all deals done resulted in lower rent going forward. Now when you go back and look at the past couple of years, however, we note that in 2009, 34% of the deals that we did rolled rent down and in 2010, 29% of them rolled rent down. That's a good trend. I'm hopeful that it will continue, although of course not necessarily in every quarter.
Occupancy the quarter remained flat with last year at 93.5%. It was up 30 basis points from year end at 93.2%. Wish I can say it's all positive from hereon out, but that's not the case as Borders closed 3 locations after the first quarter ended and Blockbuster closed the remaining 5 that they had with us. Together, that's over 100,000 square feet of vacancies that will be reflected in the next quarterly closing. And even with some pretty active new leasing going on within the portfolio, we'll almost certainly bring occupancy below 93% at June 30. On top of that, we still have one more operating Borders store in Pennsylvania and a couple of A&P Supermarkets whose future is questionable and will depend on the bankruptcy proceedings of those companies, so there is potential for additional pressure on occupancy.
Having said that, we've got some pretty positive leasing momentum under way portfolio-wise, but particularly on the West Coast. We believe that looking forward from the second quarter on, that we'll have more upside potential than downside risk in terms of occupancy.
The other important measure to look at is same-center growth, and those metrics are pretty good too. the quarter, same-center growth was 1.8% without redevelopment, and shows a negative 1.1% including redevelopment. we dig a little deeper, you'll see that, that negative 1.1% reflects a Home Depot lease termination fee last year that I mentioned earlier. Without it, same-store growth was 2.5%, pretty darn strong. 
let me talk about capital deployment a bit and give you an update on development and opportunities on the acquisition front. Let me start out west and tell you that at Santana, our ability to create significant value largely on the residential side is looking particularly promising. As Jeff noted out that 8 years after we opened the property, it has become a social and shopping hub in San Jose. As you may recall, we have entitlements to build 1,200 residential units on the site, the first 200 of which we converted to condos years ago, the next 300 we currently operate at luxury apartment, where upward pressure on rents brings future growth, leaving roughly 700 units left to build. Construction continues on budget, on time for the next 108 rental units -- rental apartments and we'll begin leasing over the summer with the first move in this fall. what we initially expected to be a 7% going-in yield is looking more like an 8% at that $34 million project. We're 1 month or 2 away from bringing plans for the next 200 units to the investment committee, with construction starting within the year. After that, we still have nearly 300 units to add.
We're also closing -- close to nailing down the contract for a sizable property acquisition on the West Coast, and redevelopment plans at West Gate Mall in Hollywood are taking shape. All in all, I feel very good about the future of our West Coast portfolio.
Coming back East, we closed on the acquisition of Tower Shops outside of Fort Lauderdale in the first quarter and an early indications of tenant interest is exceeding our expectations. That's going to be a good one. The real opportunities on the East Coast lies in the prospective development of Mid-Pike Plaza and Assembly Row in the next couple of years, both of which are progressing well at this point. Mid-Pike will of course provide better yield in the early phases, but longer-term possibility to Assembly are encouraging. First things first and that means the T Stop needs to be under construction under terms that we can live it. Earlier this week ago, the Massachusetts Transportation Authority officially put the T up for bid, another important step in a very critical process of getting public transportation to the site. would hope to have a strong indication of costs, terms and schedule on that in the next 90 days.  Plus the smaller redevelopment projects, many of them with a residential component, are moving well to the planning stages. 
In summary, despite what remains a very challenging retail leasing environment, it is an improving one and our path to future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. It will be Led by retail and nonretail development and retenanting opportunities, along with new raw material in the form of some powerful acquisitions.
That's all I've got for my prepared remarks this morning. I'd now turn the call  over to Andy and I look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy a solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollover throughout economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financial i
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. 
Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy a solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollover throughout economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financial impact of the Borders and Blockbuster bankruptcies, talk a little bit about the balance sheet and then provide a few comments on our outlook and guidance.
Turning to our quarterly results. Rental income grew a solid 3% in the quarter, roughly half of which came from the same-center pool, with the rest coming from acquisition of Huntington Square last August and Tower Shops in January. Same-center rental income growth was driven by the year-over-year impact of redevelopment stabilizations including Hampden Lane in and rents starts including Neiman Marcus Last Call Studio and Matchbox at Congressional, strong quarter rental growth once again demonstrating the quality of our properties. 
Other property income declined by $3.8 million, largely coming from the final Home Depot lease term fee at Shopping Center at Philadelphia in the first quarter 2010. expenses were flat year-over-year, as lower expenses associated with snow were offset by smaller increases in real estate taxes. As Don discussed, same-center property operating income grew 1.8% excluding redevelopment, and was 2.5% including redevelopment after adjusting for the lease term fee in first quarter 2010.
Below the operating line, we saw decreases in net interest expense driven by the repayment of our term loan in the first quarter of 2010 and the associated $2.8 million charge for early extinguishment of debt as well as the repayment of our $75 million 4.5% notes in February 2011 utilizing our line of credit. First quarter 2011 results also include a positive $300,000 debt extinguishment impact associated with the early repayment of the mortgage debt assumed in the acquisition of Tower Shop.
G&A increased $600,000 through increases in acquisition and personnel costs, as we DID preliminary work in getting a number of future redevelopment opportunities up for execution. All in, FFO per share was $0.99 per share, up 5.3% versus first quarter 2010.
First quarter operating results included full rent and recovery charges at all 4 of our Borders and our 5 Blockbuster locations, totaling about $1 million in the quarter. With 3 of our 4 Borders locations and all 5 Blockbuster locations now closed, we'll have an incremental 103,000 square feet of vacancies starting in the second quarter and anticipate rent and recoveries totaling 600,000 for the remainder of 2011 from those spaces. These negatives will certainly be offset by positive impacts including year-over-year improvements from Hampden Lane and the Santana Row, most Dick's and Ross coming online in Escondido as well as a slew of other core lease deals. While we reaffirmed our 2011 guidance, we expect some lumpiness in our quarters to achieve the full year result.
With respect to the balance sheet, we implemented an aftermarket equity program in March and successfully issued 48 million of common equity in the quarter. We believe the ATM provides cost-effective access to capital, to fluid lease funds' smaller capital needs and we utilized that program to permanently fund a significant portion of the Tower Shops acquisition in the first quarter. 
Over the course of the quarter, we repaid $75 million 4 1/2% unsecured notes at maturity and we paid a $32 million federal deposit loan on April 29. We remain on track to recast the upsized credit facility in June and have been encouraged by the strong positive momentum in the pricing of credit facilities over the past few months.  The balance sheet remains in great shape, with strong leverage and coverage metrics and significant debt capacity, especially with respect to secured debt providing a competitive advantage when sourcing acquisition opportunities. 
With another quarter behind us, we're feeling more and more confident that our 2011 FFO per share growth will be comparable to what we saw in 2010, despite the negative impact of the bankruptcies that Don and I mentioned. As a result, we've are leaving our FFO per share guidance unchanged. Key drivers include: We continue to call for positive full year same-store property operating income growth, despite near-term declines in occupancy and an over $5 million decline in expected lease term fees. G&A will be higher in 2011 that in 2010, call it $0.5 million resulting from increased acquisition costs, personnel costs and early stage redevelopment expenses. 
Finally, we're calling for improvements in year-over-year net interest expense. largest portion of this results from the $3 million swing in early extinguishment of debt that we saw in the first quarter, but also anticipates the repayment of our notes and secured debt throughout the year. Operator, I'll now turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from the line of Quentin Velleley, Citi.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot West Coast acquisition you're looking at. I'm just curious given these strengths
componenttext: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot West Coast acquisition you're looking at. I'm just curious given these strengths in residential, are you more tempted to buy assets with a greater residential exposure or maybe more development sites to take advantage of some of the strength?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Quentin, first of all, we do like mixtures and we've liked mixtures for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana. That's what you see at Assembly and given some of the redevelopment projects that we have at our shopping centers like Congressi
componenttext: Quentin, first of all, we do like mixtures and we've liked mixtures for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana. That's what you see at Assembly and given some of the redevelopment projects that we have at our shopping centers like Congressional Plaza, we're looking right now at adding another residential component to the Congressional Plaza. And that's -- all of that is kind of natural in a company that really focuses on the infill locations that we have. So yes, you look forward at over the next 5 to 7 years, and certainly the residential opportunities in terms of mixed-use and things like that, make some sense. But we're not going to go out there and -- we're not gonna go compete with the residential companies by buying purely residential projects. The difference is you'll see us maybe more willing to invest our capital in the residential component of the retail projects that we already have. I think the best way to say it is today, the residential income stream within the total rent stream of Federal is 7% or so. can certainly see that going up 10% or 11% or 12%, but we will always be a retail company.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market, there's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in real estate markets given long-term fiscal austerity risk and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market, there's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in real estate markets given long-term fiscal austerity risk and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall case th
componenttext: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall case that I think it's true. So when you look at -- when you get down to the specific markets and you have government certainly trying to skinny down, let's start with the federal government, you could say gosh, Federal's got a big concentration in DC. Are you worried about what's going on with the federal government in terms of its impact on DC? And frankly, I see it the other way. I think there will be more consolidation to DC in government agencies from other places. And so you really got to look at the specific markets. And the markets that we're operating in, I don't have that worry, Quentin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted
componenttext: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted effort to follow up on that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes it could. Craig, it is. If you go back -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing, you can't just hit the supply-side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael is
componenttext: Yes it could. Craig, it is. If you go back -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing, you can't just hit the supply-side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael is all about creating demand within our portfolio. Now our portfolio, as you know, it's very unique. It is infill. It does have some good demographics. And it does have a big advantage in that our and our are demonstrably lower than the comparable mall. Now they're higher in a lot of the other shopping centers companies, but it's a lot lower than the comparable mall. So from my perspective, to the extent we can truly use Michael's 26 years of history with General Growth and with Ralph's and with those relationships in the malls to make that pitch, whether you're talking about depending on compared to depending on city or White Marsh compared to the White Marsh Mall or a dozen other places like that throughout the country, having somebody with those relationships that we just don't have at the depth that Michael does, has to be able to create additional demand. And even if we don't pull those tenants out of the mall, we'll be creating more demand for our existing tenant against our existing tenants and may very well impact, should very well impact, our ability to renew existing tenants. So demand's a good, thing and we absolutely made, took a definitive step here With looking at our properties, looking at the advantages of our properties compared to the corresponding malls and we're going to try to create demand.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: Very good. But no, no. it is -- there is no question that we want the ability to handle more anchor stuff and be able to use Chris more on the acquisition side, more of the management role. it's just about getting some help right now. Where I go on right now, it's really a pretty exciting time. It's not 2007, but it's much tougher than that, that's for sure. But managing through these next couple of years is going to differentiate some of that, I think.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there we
componenttext: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there were a couple of years ago, but there's not an abundance. And in the markets and the trade areas in the markets where we want to buy property, it just remained very, very competitive to find good assets that we think we can have add value to over time, and I don't really see that changing for a while. Returns are very low, and we're still, we're more optimistic than we were but very cautious on the fundamental side of the business and always really looking hard at how we're going see real rents grow in the future in these trade areas. there's stuff out there certainly. It's just tough to get properties and when they come up, they're expensive.

componenttext: No, we did not. There's some more with the shops. Let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do think we've got a pretty good handle on what rents are. I think we've got a pretty good idea where rents are going. I think we do a pretty good job of redeveloping. And some of the assumptions that are being made in some of these potential acquisitions, just it's hard for us to get ourselves behind them. So that, for me, is the single big biggest thing that's stopping it. But in the one we're looking at, we're pretty quite down the road. But again, we still have some wood to chop there. You'll see what we mean if we can get down with the closing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Last question for me, in terms of where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise. But obviously, the spreads have held up pretty well and you guys have se
componenttext: Last question for me, in terms of where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise. But obviously, the spreads have held up pretty well and you guys have seen probably a more of an increase relative to other companies. But can you give us some sense of just your expectations for maybe the balance of the year or as you look forward, where you think leasing spreads could go?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: More of the same. I don't think you'll see, I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters. That's for sure. I think single-digit area is more what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in prospective comment that is the really inter
componenttext: More of the same. I don't think you'll see, I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters. That's for sure. I think single-digit area is more what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in prospective comment that is the really interesting dynamic, from my perspective at leased, is when you do look at a bunch of leases done and you say, Well, okay, within that portfolio of leases done, how many of them are really rolling down? That really has been where we've seen a real change in the last 2.5 years. There were far more deals that were rolling down than are now. It's moderate. now on the other side, it's not like we're seeing big increases like we saw. Before, those increases are still lower. But without the bottom pulling down so much, it's obviously popping up and looking a lot better. It's a more of a moderating leasing environment than it is an extreme one, at least in our a portfolio, and that's the big difference.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Alex Goldfarb, Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments, sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop at 7 or 8 because you already own the dirt a
componenttext: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments, sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop at 7 or 8 because you already own the dirt and you can sell some of those for sub-5, that's a pretty significant profit margin and obviously, it's a good backdrop right now to sell apartments. So one is curious about just from a capital recycling perspective, crystallizing the value that you guys create, and two, as you think about NOI volatility, certainly apartment NOI streams are a lot a lot more volatile than your shopping center portfolio. So just cures about how you think about those two.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, those are good questions and you should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building, and let's talk about Santana because that is biggest piece is being built at condo spec, and these are nice units. And I agree because
componenttext: Sure, those are good questions and you should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building, and let's talk about Santana because that is biggest piece is being built at condo spec, and these are nice units. And I agree because we have costs back or land costs back in 1997, '98, 2000. You've got an advantage. We plan on certainly the units that we're building now, the 108 and probably the next set too at the appropriate time, monetizing and get paid for it. And when we started this, what we knew is that you can't time that exactly right. You never can. So to the extent we can rent them and even earn a 5.5% or 6% return until we can monetize with condos, we would. It's turning out that our timing is particularly good for once in Santana and we're able to get better rental yields. But the long-term plan is exactly as you had laid out. Secondly, with respect to NOI volatility, absolutely right. And one of the things that we pride ourselves on is taking this entire portfolio and running it for the purpose of creating a steadily growing income stream. And that means not relying too much on any one type, and that's apartment rentals stream falls right into that line. It will not be a huge part of the company. It will be a little bit bigger than it is today, but still small and the same applies to our retail. We do have lifestyle centers in here. We have grocery-anchored shopping centers in here. We have basically every kind of retail, other than malls, in here. And that diversity really does help us create the stability that we have, and we are very, very honed to make sure that in all of our business plans that, that's the product that we continue to offer. So I hope that helps.

componenttextpreview: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.
componenttext: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there necessarily at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we've done
componenttext: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there necessarily at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we've done with Avalon and may continue to do with Avalon. So it really will depend on the project. It depends unit by unit. But as I say, the whole -- we are very value-added focus. And we evaluate the condo risk, we evaluate the rental risk and against what we can get paid for that and make those decisions. So it's really a deal-by-deal analysis that we do.

componenttext: Yes, Laura, I think we've talked about this when we were together in California. On the small shop side, it is more -- even more than nationally, it is more dependent upon the location. And a lot of the small shop tenants that were really struggling have either gone away or have figured out a way to operate at the sales levels that they are at because they're looking at those sales levels getting more positive. So we are having a much better set of circumstances in being able to renew them. No most of them, as I was saying before, are not being renewed at anywhere near the increases that they were last year, in the good old days if you will. But they are much less likely to go away. And so while it's still a soft piece, if you will, of the business, it's a very manageable piece of the business. And I suspect if you talked to others that you would see a really big difference based on the demographics of the location of a particular property with respect to my comments. I suggest that I don't believe applies in those secondary and tertiary, where I don't think it's much better at all.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Bird
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. 
Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These, and other members of our management team, are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Our first quarter 2011 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the trust's operating and financial performance. This document is currently available on our website. 
Federal Realty is also now in Twitter, and you can follow us for news and updates with our Twitter handle, @FederalRealty.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events our results. 
Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected on such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give you no assurance that these expectations will be attained.
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but not are limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks in costs of construction. 
The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of first quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quarter, we took about $0.05-a-share hit for an early extinguishment of debt charge, but we also booked a about $0.05-per-share benefit from the end of the large -- end of a large lease termination fee from Home Depot. Those 2 transactions, more or less, offset last year. And so, with or without them, we'd still be reporting about a 5% increase this quarter.
Now let's dig into the quarter a bit. 91 leases executed for 340,000 feet of space, and new average rents of $30.52, 11% higher than the $27.55 per foot that they replaced. Michaels is replacing Foot Locker at Bala Cynwyd Shopping Center, and LA Fitness is replacing Toys R Us at Laurel Shopping Center, along with a couple of bank pad renewals led the increase. 
There are, certainly, still deals that we're making, where rental rates are moving down. And in my opinion, there will continue to be deals like that for the foreseeable future. But those deals are making up smaller and smaller percentage. 
For example, in this first quarter, of the 91 comparable leases signed, 19 of them rolled rent down. Thus, 21% of all deals done resulted in lower rent going forward. Now when you go back and look at the past couple of years, however, we note that in 2009, 34% of the deals that we did rolled rent down. And in 2010, 29% of them rolled rent down. 
That's a good trend. I'm hopeful that it will continue, although, of course, not necessarily in every quarter.
Occupancy in the quarter remained flat with last year at 93.5%. It was up 30 basis points from year-end at 93.2%. Wish I could say that it's all positive from hereon out, but that's not the case as Borders closed 3 locations after the first quarter ended and Blockbuster closed the remaining 5 that they had with us. 
Together, that's over 100,000 square feet of vacancies that will be reflected in the next quarterly closing. And even with some pretty active new leasing going on within the portfolio, we'll almost certainly bring occupancy below 93% at June 30. 
On top of that, we'd still have one more operating Borders store win in Pennsylvania and a couple of A&P Supermarkets, whose future is questionable, and will depend on the bankruptcy proceedings of those companies. And so, there is potential for additional pressure on occupancy.
But having said that, we've got some pretty positive leasing momentum under way, portfolio-wide, particularly on the West Coast. We believe that looking forward from the second quarter on, that we'll have more upside potential than downside risk in terms of occupancy.
The other important measure to look at is same-center growth, and those metrics are pretty good, too. The quarter, same-center growth was 1.8% without redevelopment and shows a negative 1.1% including redevelopment. If we dig a little deeper, you'll see that, that negative 1.1% reflects a Home Depot lease termination fee last year that I mentioned earlier. Without it, same-store growth was 2.5%, pretty darn strong.
Okay. Let me talk about capital deployment a bit and give you an update on development and opportunities on the acquisition front. Let me start out west and tell you that at Santana [Santana Row], our ability to create significant value, largely on the residential side, is looking particularly promising.  As Jeff noted out that 8 years after we opened the property, it has become the social and shopping hub of San Jose. 
As you may recall, we have entitlements to build 1,200 residential units on this site, the first 200 of which we converted to condos years ago. The next 300, we currently operate at as terrific luxury apartments, where upward pressure on rents brings great future growth, leaving roughly 700 units left to build. 
Construction continues on budget, on time for the next 108 rental units -- rental apartments, and we'll begin leasing over the summer, with the first move in this fall. What was initially expected to be a 7% going-in yield is looking more like an 8% at that $34 million project. 
We're 1 month or 2 away from bringing plans for the next 200 units set to investment committee, with construction starting within the year. After that, we still have nearly 300 units to add.
We're also closing -- close to nailing down the contract for a sizable property acquisition on the West Coast, and redevelopment plans at Westgate Mall in Hollywood are taking shape. All in all, I feel very good about the future of our West Coast portfolio.
Coming back East, we closed on the acquisition of Tower Shops outside of Fort Lauderdale in the first quarter and early indications of tenant interest is exceeding our expectations. That's going to be a good one. 
The real opportunities on the East Coast lies in the prospective development of Mid-Pike Plaza and Assembly Row in the next couple of years, both of which are progressing well at this point. Mid-Pike will, of course, provide better yields in the early phases, but longer-term possibility to Assembly are encouraging. 
Of course, first things first, and that means the T-Stop needs to get under construction under terms that we can live it. Earlier this week though, the Massachusetts Transportation Authority [Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority] officially puts the T [T-Stop] out for bid, another important step in a very critical process of getting public transportation to the site. 
We would hope to have a strong indication of costs, terms and schedule on that in the next 90 days.  
Lots of smaller redevelopment projects. Many of them with a residential component are moving well to the planning stages, too.
In summary, despite what remains a very challenging retail leasing environment, it is an improving one and our path to future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. It will be led by retail and nonretail development and retenanting opportunities, along with new raw material in the form of some powerful acquisitions.
That's all I've got for my prepared remarks this morning. I'd now turn the call over to Andy, and I'll look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy and solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollovers throughout the economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy and solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollovers throughout the economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financial impact of the Borders and Blockbuster bankruptcies, talk a little bit about the balance sheet and then, provide a few comments on our outlook and guidance.
Turning to our quarterly results. Rental income grew a solid 3% in the quarter, roughly half of which came from the same-center pool, with the rest coming from acquisition of Huntington Square last August and Tower Shops in January. 
Same-center rental income growth was driven by the year-over-year impact of redevelopment stabilizations including Hampden Lane in Bethesda and rents starts including Neiman Marcus Last Call Studio and Matchbox at Congressional [Congressional Plaza], strong quarter rental growth, once again, demonstrating the quality of our properties.
Other property income declined by $3.8 million, largely coming from the final Home Depot lease term fee at Flourtown Shopping Center at Philadelphia in first quarter 2010. 
Property expenses were flat year-over-year, as lower expenses associated with snow were offset by smaller increases in real estate taxes. As Don discussed, same-center property operating income grew 1.8%, excluding redevelopment, and was 2.5% including redevelopment after adjusting for the lease term fee in first quarter 2010.
Below the operating line, we saw decreases in net interest expense driven by the repayment of our term loan in first quarter 2010 and the associated $2.8 million charge for early extinguishment of debt, as well as the repayment of our $75 million 4.5% notes in February 2011, utilizing our line of credit. 
First quarter 2011 results also include a positive $300,000 debt extinguishment impact associated with the early repayment of the mortgage debt assumed in the acquisition of Tower Shop.
G&A increased $600,000 through increases in acquisition and personnel costs, as we did preliminary work in getting a number of those future redevelopment opportunities tuned up for execution. 
All in, FFO per share was $0.99 per share, up 5.3% versus first quarter 2010.
First quarter operating results included full rent and recovery charges at all 4 of our Borders and our 5 Blockbuster locations, totaling about $1 million in the quarter. With 3 of our 4 Borders locations and all 5 Blockbuster locations now closed, we'll have an incremental 103,000 square feet of vacancies starting in the second quarter and anticipate rent and recoveries totaling 600,000 for the remainder of 2011 from those spaces. 
These negatives will certainly be offset by positive impacts including year-over-year improvements from Hampden Lane in Bethesda and the 300 Santana Row, both most Dick's [Dick's Sporting Goods] and Ross coming online at Escondido, as well as a slew of other core lease deals. 
While we reaffirmed our 2011 guidance, we expect some lumpiness in our quarters to achieve the full year result.
With respect to the balance sheet, we implemented an aftermarket equity program in March and successfully issued 48 million of common equity in the quarter. We believe the ATM provides cost-effective access to capital, to fluid lease funds' smaller capital needs, and we utilized that program to permanently fund a significant portion of the Tower Shops acquisition in the first quarter.
Over the course of the quarter, we repaid $75 million 4 1/2% unsecured notes at maturity, and we paid the $32 million Federal Deposit loan on April 29. 
We remain on track to recast the upsized credit facility in June and have been encouraged by the strong positive momentum in the pricing of credit facilities over the past few months. 
The balance sheet remains in great shape, with strong leverage and coverage metrics and significant debt capacity, especially with respect to secured debt, providing a competitive advantage when sourcing acquisition opportunities. 
With another quarter behind us, we're feeling more and more confident that our 2011 FFO per share growth will be comparable to what we saw in 2010, despite the negative impact of the bankruptcies both Don and I mentioned. As a result, we're leaving our FFO per share guidance unchanged. 
Key drivers include: We continue to call for positive full year same-store property operating income growth, despite near-term declines in occupancy and an over $5 million decline in expected lease term fees; G&A will be higher in 2011 that in 2010, call it $500,000, resulting from increased acquisition costs, personnel costs and early stage redevelopment expenses. 
Finally, we're calling for improvements in year-over-year net interest expense. The largest portion of this results from the $3 million swing in early extinguishment of debt that we saw in the first quarter, but also anticipates the repayment of our notes and secured debt throughout the year. 
Operator, I'll now turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from the line of Quentin Velleley, Citi.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular, the Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot of West Coast acquisition you're looking at. I'm just curious, given these s
componenttext: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular, the Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot of West Coast acquisition you're looking at. I'm just curious, given these strengths in residential, are you more tempted to buy assets with a greater residential exposure or maybe more development sites to take advantage of some of the strength?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Quentin, first of all, the -- we do like mixed-use, and we've liked mixed-use for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana, that's what you see at Assembly. And given some of the redevelopment projects that we have in our shopping cente
componenttext: Well, Quentin, first of all, the -- we do like mixed-use, and we've liked mixed-use for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana, that's what you see at Assembly. And given some of the redevelopment projects that we have in our shopping centers like Congressional Plaza, we're looking hard now at adding another residential component to the back at Congressional Plaza. And that's -- all of that is kind of natural in a company that really focuses on the infill location sets that we have. So yes, you look forward at over the next 5 to 7 years, and certainly, the residential opportunities in terms of mixed-use and things like that, make some sense. But we're not going to go out there and -- we're not gonna go compete with the residential companies by buying purely residential projects. The difference is, you'll see us maybe more willing to invest our capital in the residential component of the retail projects that we already have. I think the best way to say it is today, our -- the residential income stream within the total rent stream of Federal is 7% or so. You can certainly see that going up 10% or 11% or 12%, but we will always be a retail company.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market. There's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in real estate markets, given long-term fiscal austerity risk and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market. There's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in real estate markets, given long-term fiscal austerity risk and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. Now that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall cas
componenttext: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. Now that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall case that I think it's true. So when you look at -- when you get down to the specific markets and you have government certainly trying to skinny down, I mean let's start with the federal government, you could say, "oh gosh, Federal's got a big concentration in DC." Are you worried about what's going on with the federal government in terms of its impact on DC? And frankly, I see it the other way. I think there'll be more consolidation to DC in government agencies from other places. And so you really got to look at the specific markets. And in the markets that we're operating in, I don't have that worry, Quentin, no.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted
componenttext: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted effort to follow up on that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig, it is. If you go back , if you -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing -- you can't just hit the supply side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael
componenttext: Yes, Craig, it is. If you go back , if you -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing -- you can't just hit the supply side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael is all about creating demand within our portfolio. Now our portfolio, as you know, was very unique. It is infill. It does have to have some good demographics. And it does have a big advantage in that tax, and our extras demonstrably lower than the comparable mall. Now they're higher, it's higher in a lot of the other shopping centers companies, so it's a lot lower than a comparable mall. So from my perspective, to the extent we can truly use Michael's 26 years of history with General Growth and with Ralph's and with those relationships in the malls to make that pitch, whether you're talking about depending on compared to depending on city or White Marsh compared to the White Marsh Mall or a dozen other places like that throughout the country, having somebody with those relationships that we just don't have to the depth that Michael does, thus to be able to create additional demand. And even if we don't pull those tenants out of the mall, we'll be creating more demand for our existing tenant against our existing tenants and may very well impact -- should very well impact our ability to renew existing tenants. So demand's a good thing and we absolutely made -- took a definitive step here. With looking at our properties, looking at the advantages of our properties compared to the corresponding malls and we're going to try to create demand.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. I look forward to seeing how that plays out. I guess it will take some time, but -- and you also hired Lance Billingsley. Is that because there's more movement in the anchor space? Or you're just trying to give Chris [Chris Weilminster] a life and
componenttext: Great. I look forward to seeing how that plays out. I guess it will take some time, but -- and you also hired Lance Billingsley. headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory, anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there w
componenttext: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory, anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there were a couple of years ago, but there's not an abundance. And in the markets and the trade areas within the markets where we want to buy a property, it just remained very, very competitive to find good assets that we think we can have value to over time. And I don't really see that changing for a while. Returns are very low, and we're still -- we're more optimistic than we were, but very cautious on the fundamental side of the business and always really looking hard at how we're going see real rents grow in the future in these trade areas. So there's stuff out there certainly. It's just that it's tough to get properties and when they come up, they're expensive.

componenttextpreview: No, we did not. There's some more woods to chop. Let us get through that -- let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do
componenttext: No, we did not. There's some more woods to chop. Let us get through that -- let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do think we've got a pretty good handle on what rents are. I think we've got a pretty good idea where rents are going. I think we do a pretty good job of redeveloping. And some of the assumptions that are being made in some of these potential acquisitions, it's just -- it's hard for us to get ourselves behind them. So that, for me, is the single biggest thing that's stopping it. But in the one we're looking at, we're pretty quite down the road. But again, we still have some wood to chop there. You'll see what I -- you'll see what we mean, if we can get down with the closing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And then just last question for me. In terms of just where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise, but obviously, the spreads are -- have held
componenttext: Helpful. And then just last question for me. In terms of just where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise, but obviously, the spreads are -- have held up pretty well and you guys have seen probably a more of an increase relative to other companies. But can you give us some sense of just your expectations for maybe the balance of the year or as you look forward, where you think leasing spreads could go?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, more of the same. I don't think you'll see -- I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters, that's for sure. I think the single-digit area is more of what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in a prospective comment that is
componenttext: Yes, more of the same. I don't think you'll see -- I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters, that's for sure. I think the single-digit area is more of what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in a prospective comment that is the really interesting dynamic, from my perspective at least, is when you do look at a bunch of leases done and you say, "well, okay, within that portfolio of leases done, how many of them are really rolling down?" That really has been where we've seen a real, the most of change in the last 2.5 years. There were far more deals that were rolling down than there are now. It's moderate. Now on the other side, it's not like we're seeing big increases like we saw before. Those increases are still lower. But without the bottom pulling down so much there, it's obviously popping up and looking a lot better. It's a more of a moderating leasing environment than it is an extreme one, at least in our a portfolio, and that's the big difference.
