headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments. A sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop about 7 or 8 because you already own the d
componenttext: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments. A sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop about 7 or 8 because you already own the dirt and you can sell some of those for sub-5, that's a pretty significant profit margin and obviously, it's a good backdrop right now to sell apartments. So one is curious about just from a capital recycling perspective, crystallizing the value that you guys create, and two, as you think about NOI volatility, certainly, apartment NOI streams are a lot more volatile than shopping center -- than your shopping center portfolio. So just curious about how you think about those 2.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, those are good questions and hand in hand. You should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building -- and let's talk about Santana because there is -- that is the biggest piece of -- that's being built at condo spec. And
componenttext: Sure, those are good questions and hand in hand. You should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building -- and let's talk about Santana because there is -- that is the biggest piece of -- that's being built at condo spec. And these are nice units. And I agree, because we have costs back or land costs back to 2000 -- 1997, '98, 2000. You've got -- we're on advantage. We plan on, certainly, the units that we're building now, the 108 and probably, the next set, too, at the appropriate time, monetize and get paid for it. And when we started this, what we knew is that you can't time that exactly right. You never can. So to the extent we can rent them and even earn a 5.5% or 6% return until we can monetize with condos, we would. It's turning out that our timing is particularly good, for once, in Santana, and we're able to get better rental yields. But the long-term plan is exactly as you had laid out. Secondly, with respect to NOI volatility, you're absolutely right. And one of the things that we pride ourselves on is taking this entire portfolio and running it for the purpose of creating a steadily growing income stream. And that means not relying too much on any one type, and that apartment rentals stream falls right into that line. It will not be a huge part of the company. It will be a little bit bigger than it is today, but still small. And the same applies to our retail side. We do have lifestyle centers in here. We have grocery-anchored shopping centers in here. We have basically every kind of retail, other than malls, in here. And that diversity really does help us create the stability that we have, and we're very, very honed to make sure that in all of our business plans that, that's the product that we continue to offer. So I hope that helps.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.
componenttext: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do lose -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there, necessarily, at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we'
componenttext: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do lose -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there, necessarily, at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we've done, with Avalon [AvonlonBay Communities] and may continue to do with Avalon. So it really will depend on the project. It depends unit by unit. But as I say, the whole -- we are very value-added focus. And we evaluate the condo risk, we evaluate the rental risk and -- against what we can get paid for that and make those decisions. So it's really a deal-by-deal analysis that we do.

componenttextpreview: Nathan, as I sit here, whenever it is, May 5, 6 of 2011, I don't see that. I think from an internal growth perspective, I continue to believe that over the long term that we will outperform. But the forces and factors that were in place during '05, '06, '
componenttext: Nathan, as I sit here, whenever it is, May 5, 6 of 2011, I don't see that. I think from an internal growth perspective, I continue to believe that over the long term that we will outperform. But the forces and factors that were in place during '05, '06, '07, they're just not going to be here. And you have to find -- we have to find, and we're looking pretty hard to find other ways than a REIT-congested basis to grow. So again, we'll be relatively better, I very much believe, but 2007 is long gone.

componenttextpreview: Well, in the first space, I think we've said assuming we get that T Stop started -- and that is looking more and more likely, not definitive, but more and more likely, that we are prepared to start Phase 1. That Phase 1 will start late this year, may be e
componenttext: Well, in the first space, I think we've said assuming we get that T Stop started -- and that is looking more and more likely, not definitive, but more and more likely, that we are prepared to start Phase 1. That Phase 1 will start late this year, may be early next year, but we're even trying hopefully to get it started late this year. But the yields will not be supporting, and so they will not add significant effort for growth from that first $120 million or so that it will be take in Phase 1. The future entitlement build-out, we're certainly very, very about. But doing this first phase right to be able to create this place is important to us. it's just not going to give us a ton of FFO growth. I hope Mid-Pike will, though. And Mid-Pike Plaza will start a year from now or 15 months from now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Laura, I think we've talked about this when we were together in California. On the small shop side, it is more -- even more than nationally, it is more dependent upon the location. And a lot of the small shop tenants that were really struggling have
componenttext: Yes, Laura, I think we've talked about this when we were together in California. On the small shop side, it is more -- even more than nationally, it is more dependent upon the location. And a lot of the small shop tenants that were really struggling have either gone away or have figured out a way to operate at the sales levels that they are at because they're looking at those sales levels getting more positive. So we are having a much better set of circumstances in being able to renew them. No most of them, as I was saying before, are not being renewed at anywhere near the increases that they were last year, in the good old days if you will. But they are much less likely to go away. And so while it's still a soft piece, if you will, of the business, it's a very manageable piece of the business. And I suspect if you talked to others that you would see a really big difference based on the demographics of the location of a particular property with respect to my comments. I suggest that I don't believe applies in those secondary and tertiary, where I don't think it's much better at all.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Bird
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. 
Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These, and other members of our management team, are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Our first quarter 2011 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the trust's operating and financial performance. This document is currently available on our website. 
Federal Realty is also now on Twitter, and you can follow us for news and updates with our Twitter handle, @FederalRealty.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events our results. 
Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected on such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained.
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but not are limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. 
The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of first quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quarter, we took about $0.05-a-share hit for an early extinguishment of debt charge, but we also booked at about $0.05-per-share benefit from the end of the large -- end of a large lease termination fee from Home Depot. Those 2 transactions, more or less, offset last year. And so, with or without them, we'd still be reporting about a 5% increase this quarter.
Now let's dig into the quarter a bit. 91 leases executed for 340,000 feet of space, and new average rents of $30.52, 11% higher than the $27.55 per foot that they replaced. Michaels is replacing Foot Locker at Bala Cynwyd Shopping Center, and LA Fitness is replacing Toys R Us at Laurel Shopping Center, along with a couple of bank pad renewals led the increase. 
There are, certainly, still deals that we're making, where rental rates are moving down. And in my opinion, there will continue to be deals like that for the foreseeable future. But those deals are making up smaller and smaller percentage. 
For example, in this first quarter, of the 91 comparable leases signed, 19 of them rolled rent down. Thus, 21% of all deals done resulted in lower rent going forward. Now when you go back and look at the past couple of years, however, we note that in 2009, 34% of the deals that we did rolled rent down. And in 2010, 29% of them rolled rent down. 
That's a good trend. I'm hopeful that it will continue, although, of course, not necessarily in every quarter.
Occupancy in the quarter remained flat with last year at 93.5%. It was up 30 basis points from year-end at 93.2%. Wish I could say that it's all positive from here on out, but that's not the case as Borders closed 3 locations after the first quarter ended and Blockbuster closed the remaining 5 that they had with us. 
Together, that's over 100,000 square feet of vacancies that will be reflected in the next quarterly closing. And even with some pretty active new leasing going on within the portfolio, we'll almost certainly bring occupancy below 93% at June 30. 
On top of that, we'd still have one more operating Borders store Winwood, Pennsylvania and a couple of A&P Supermarkets, whose future is questionable, and will depend on the bankruptcy proceedings of those companies. And so, there is potential for additional pressure on occupancy.
But having said that, we've got some pretty positive leasing momentum under way, portfolio-wide, particularly on the West Coast. We believe that looking forward from the second quarter on, that we'll have more upside potential than downside risk in terms of occupancy.
The other important measure to look at is same-center growth, and those metrics are pretty good, too. The quarter, same-center growth was 1.8% without redevelopment and shows a negative 1.1% including redevelopment. Or if we dig a little deeper, you'll see that, that negative 1.1% reflects a Home Depot lease termination fee last year that I mentioned earlier. Without it, same-store growth was 2.5%, pretty darn strong.
Okay. Let me talk about capital deployment a bit and give you an update on development and opportunities on the acquisition front. Let me start out west and tell you that at Santana [Santana Row], our ability to create significant value, largely on the residential side, is looking particularly promising.  As Jeff noted out that 8 years after we opened the property, it has become the social and shopping hub of San Jose. 
As you may recall, we have entitlements to build 1,200 residential units on this site, the first 200 of which we converted to condos years ago. The next 300, we currently operate at as terrific luxury apartments, where upward pressure on rents brings great future growth, leaving roughly 700 units left to build. 
Construction continues on budget, on time for the next 108 rental units -- rental apartments, and we'll begin leasing over the summer, with the first move ins this fall. What was initially expected to be a 7% going-in yield is looking more like an 8% at that $34 million project. 
We're 1 month or 2 away from bringing plans for the next 200 units set to investment committee, with construction starting within the year. After that, we still have nearly 300 units to add.
We're also closing -- close to nailing down the contract for a sizable property acquisition on the West Coast, and redevelopment plans at Westgate Mall in Hollywood are taking shape. All in all, I feel very good about the future of our West Coast portfolio.
Coming back East, we closed on the acquisition of Tower Shops outside of Fort Lauderdale in the first quarter and early indications of tenant interest is exceeding our expectations. That's going to be a good one. 
The real opportunities on the East Coast lie in the prospective development of Mid-Pike Plaza and Assembly Row in the next couple of years, both of which are progressing well at this point. Mid-Pike will, of course, provide better yields in the early phases, but longer-term possibilities at Assembly are encouraging. 
Of course, first things first, and that means the T-Stop needs to get under construction under terms that we can live it. Earlier this week though, the Massachusetts Transportation Authority [Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority] officially puts the T [T-Stop] out for bid, another important step in a very critical process of getting public transportation to the site. 
We would hope to have a strong indication of costs, terms and schedule on that in the next 90 days.  
Lots of smaller redevelopment projects. Many of them with a residential component are moving well through the planning stages, too.
In summary, despite what remains a very challenging retail leasing environment, it is an improving one and our path to future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. It will be led by retail and nonretail development and retenanting opportunities, along with new raw material in the form of some powerful acquisitions.
That's all I've got for my prepared remarks this morning. I'd now turn the call over to Andy, and I'll look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy and solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollovers throughout the economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy and solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollovers throughout the economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financial impact of the Borders and Blockbuster bankruptcies, talk a little bit about the balance sheet and then, provide a few comments on our outlook and guidance.
Turning to our quarterly results. Rental income grew a solid 3% in the quarter, roughly half of which came from the same-center pool, with the rest coming from acquisition of Huntington Square last August and Tower Shops in January. 
Same-center rental income growth was driven by the year-over-year impact of redevelopment stabilizations including Hampden Lane in Bethesda and rents starts including Neiman Marcus Last Call Studio and Matchbox at Congressional [Congressional Plaza], strong core rental growth, once again, demonstrating the quality of our properties.
Other property income declined by $3.8 million, largely coming from the final Home Depot lease term fee at Flourtown Shopping Center at Philadelphia in first quarter 2010. 
Property expenses were flat year-over-year, as lower expenses associated with snow were offset by smaller increases in real estate taxes. As Don discussed, same-center property operating income grew 1.8%, excluding redevelopment, and was 2.5% including redevelopment after adjusting for the lease term fee in first quarter 2010.
Below the operating line, we saw decreases in net interest expense driven by the repayment of our term loan in first quarter 2010 and the associated $2.8 million charge for early extinguishment of debt, as well as the repayment of our $75 million 4.5% notes in February 2011, utilizing our line of credit. 
First quarter 2011 results also include a positive $300,000 debt extinguishment impact associated with the early repayment of the mortgage debt assumed in the acquisition of Tower Shop.
G&A increased $600,000 through increases in acquisition and personnel costs, as we did preliminary work in getting a number of those future redevelopment opportunities tuned up for execution. 
All in, FFO per share was $0.99 per share, up 5.3% versus first quarter 2010.
First quarter operating results included full rent and recovery charges at all 4 of our Borders and our 5 Blockbuster locations, totaling about $1 million in the quarter. With 3 of our 4 Borders locations and all 5 Blockbuster locations now closed, we'll have an incremental 103,000 square feet of vacancies starting in the second quarter and anticipate rent and recoveries totaling 600,000 for the remainder of 2011 from those spaces. 
These negatives will certainly be offset by positive impacts including year-over-year improvements from Hampden Lane in Bethesda and the 300 Santana Row, both most Dick's [Dick's Sporting Goods] and Ross coming online at Escondido, as well as a slew of other core lease deals. 
While we reaffirmed our 2011 guidance, we expect some lumpiness in our quarters to achieve the full year result.
With respect to the balance sheet, we implemented an at-the-market equity program in March and successfully issued 48 million of common equity in the quarter. We believe the ATM provides cost-effective access to capital, to fluid lease funds' smaller capital needs, and we utilized that program to permanently fund a significant portion of the Tower Shops acquisition in the first quarter.
Over the course of the quarter, we repaid the $75 million 4 1/2% unsecured notes at maturity, and repaid the $32 million Federal Deposit loan on April 29. 
We remain on track to recast the upsized credit facility in June and have been encouraged by the strong positive momentum in the pricing of credit facilities over the past few months. 
The balance sheet remains in great shape, with strong leverage and coverage metrics and significant debt capacity, especially with respect to secured debt, providing a competitive advantage when sourcing acquisition opportunities. 
With another quarter behind us, we're feeling more and more confident that our 2011 FFO per share growth will be comparable to what we saw in 2010, despite the negative impact of the bankruptcies both Don and I mentioned. As a result, we're leaving our FFO per share guidance unchanged. 
Key drivers include: We continue to call for positive full year same-store property operating income growth, despite near-term declines in occupancy and an over $5 million decline in expected lease term fees; G&A will be higher in 2011 than in 2010, call it $500,000, resulting from increased acquisition costs, personnel costs and early stage redevelopment expenses. 
Finally, we're calling for improvements in year-over-year net interest expense. The largest portion of this results from the $3 million swing in early extinguishment of debt that we saw in the first quarter, but also anticipates the repayment of our notes and secured debt throughout the year. 
Operator, I'll now turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from the line of Quentin Velleley, Citi.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular, the Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot of West Coast acquisitions you're looking at. I'm just curious, given the st
componenttext: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular, the Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot of West Coast acquisitions you're looking at. I'm just curious, given the strength in residential, are you more tempted to buy assets with a greater residential exposure or maybe more development sites to take advantage of some of the strength?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Quentin, first of all, the -- we do like mixed-use, and we've liked mixed-use for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana, that's what you see at Assembly. And even some of the redevelopment projects that we have in our shopping center
componenttext: Well, Quentin, first of all, the -- we do like mixed-use, and we've liked mixed-use for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana, that's what you see at Assembly. And even some of the redevelopment projects that we have in our shopping centers like Congressional Plaza, we're looking hard now at adding another residential component to the back at Congressional Plaza. And that's -- all of that is kind of natural in a company that really focuses on the infill location sites that we have. So yes, you look forward at over the next 5 to 7 years, and certainly, the residential opportunities in terms of mixed-use and things like that, make some sense. But we're not going to go out there and -- we're not going to go compete with the residential companies by buying purely residential projects. The difference is, you'll see us maybe more willing to invest our capital in the residential component of the retail projects that we already have. I think the best way to say it is today, our -- the residential income stream within the total rent stream of Federal is 7% or so. You can certainly see that going up 10% or 11% or 12%, but we will always be a retail company.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market. There's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in certain real estate markets, given long-term fiscal austerity risks and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market. There's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in certain real estate markets, given long-term fiscal austerity risks and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. Now that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall cas
componenttext: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. Now that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall case that I think is true. So when you look at -- when you get down to the specific markets and you have government certainly trying to skinny down, I mean let's start with the federal government, you could say, "oh gosh, Federal's got a big concentration in DC." Are you worried about what's going on with the federal government in terms of its impact on DC? And frankly, I see it the other way. I think there'll be more consolidation to DC in government agencies from other places. And so you really got to look at the specific markets. And in the markets that we're operating in, I don't have that worry, Quentin, no.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's interesting.
componenttext: Okay, that's interesting.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted
componenttext: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted effort to follow up on that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig, it is. If you go back , if you -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing -- you can't just hit the supply side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael
componenttext: Yes, Craig, it is. If you go back , if you -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing -- you can't just hit the supply side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael is all about creating demand within our portfolio. Now our portfolio, as you know, was very unique. It is infill. It does have to have some good demographics. And it does have a big advantage in that our--tax, and our extras are demonstrably lower than the comparable mall. Now they're higher, it's higher in a lot of the other shopping centers companies, so it's a lot lower than a comparable mall. So from my perspective, to the extent we can truly use Michael's 26 years of history with General Growth and with Ralph's and with those relationships in the malls to make that pitch, whether you're talking about Pentagon Row compared to Pentagon City or White Marsh compared to the White Marsh Mall or a dozen other places like that throughout the country, having somebody with those relationships that we just don't have to the depth that Michael does, thus to be able to create additional demand. And even if we don't pull those tenants out of the mall, we'll be creating more demand for our existing tenant against our existing tenants and may very well impact -- should very well impact our ability to renew existing tenants. So demand's a good thing and we absolutely made -- took a definitive step here. With looking at our properties, looking at the advantage of our properties compared to the corresponding malls and we're going to try to create demand.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory, anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there w
componenttext: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory, anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there were a couple of years ago, but there's not an abundance. And in the markets and the trade areas within the markets where we want to buy property, it just remained very, very competitive to find good assets that we think we can add value to over time. And I don't really see that changing for a while. Returns are very low, and we're still-- certainly more optimistic than we were, but very cautious on the fundamental side of the business and always really looking hard at how we're going see real rents grow in the future in these trade areas. So there's stuff out there certainly. It's just that it's tough to get the good properties and when they come up, they're expensive.

componenttext: It isn't sizeable.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we did not. There's some more woods to chop. Let us get through that -- let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do
componenttext: No, we did not. There's some more woods to chop. Let us get through that -- let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do think we've got a pretty good handle on what rents are. I think we've got a pretty good idea where rents are going. I think we do a pretty good job of redeveloping. And some of the assumptions that are being made in some of these potential acquisitions,  just -- it's hard for us to get ourselves behind them. So that, for me, is the single biggest thing that's stopping it. But in the one we're looking at, we're pretty far down the road. But again, we still have some wood to chop there. You'll see what I -- you'll see what we mean, if we can get down with the closing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And then just last question for me. In terms of just where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise, but obviously, the spreads are -- have held
componenttext: Helpful. And then just last question for me. In terms of just where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise, but obviously, the spreads are -- have held up pretty well and you guys have seen probably a more of an increase relative to other companies. But can you give us some sense of just your expectations for maybe the balance of the year or as you look forward, where you think leasing spreads could go?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, more of the same. I don't think you'll see -- I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters, that's for sure. I think the single-digit area is more of what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in prospective comments that is t
componenttext: Yes, more of the same. I don't think you'll see -- I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters, that's for sure. I think the single-digit area is more of what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in prospective comments that is the really interesting dynamic, from my perspective at least, is when you do look at a bunch of leases done and you say, "Well, okay, within that portfolio of leases done, how many of them are really rolling down?" That really has been where we've seen a real, demonstrable change in the last 2.5 years. There were far more deals that were rolling down than there are now. It's moderate. Now on the other side, it's not like we're seeing big increases like we saw before. Those increases are still lower. But without the bottom pulling down so much there, it's obviously popping up and looking a lot better. It's a more of a moderating leasing environment than it is an extreme one, at least in our portfolio, and that's the big difference.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Helpful.
componenttext: Great. Helpful.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from the line of Alex Goldfarb, Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question will come from the line of Alex Goldfarb, Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments. A sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop about 7 or 8 because you already own the d
componenttext: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments. A sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop about 7 or 8 because you already own the dirt and you can sell some of those for sub-5, that's a pretty significant profit margin and obviously, it's a good backdrop right now to sell apartments. So one is curious about just from a capital recycling perspective, crystallizing the value that you guys create, and two, as you think about NOI volatility, certainly, apartment NOI streams are a lot more volatile than shopping center -- than your shopping center portfolio. So just curious about how you think about those 2.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, those are good questions and hand in hand. You should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building -- and let's talk about Santana because there is -- that is the biggest piece of -- that's being built at condo spec. And
componenttext: Sure, those are good questions and hand in hand. You should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building -- and let's talk about Santana because there is -- that is the biggest piece of -- that's being built at condo spec. And these are nice units. And I agree, because we have costs back or land costs back to 2000 -- 1997, '98, 2000. You've got -- we're at an advantage. We plan on, certainly, the units that we're building now, the 108 and probably, the next set, too, at the appropriate time, monetize and get paid for it. And when we started this, what we knew is that you can't time that exactly right. You never can. So to the extent we can rent them and even earn a 5.5% or 6% return until we can monetize with condos, we would. It's turning out that our timing is particularly good, for once, in Santana, and we're able to get better rental yields. But the long-term plan is exactly as you had laid out. Secondly, with respect to NOI volatility, you're absolutely right. And one of the things that we pride ourselves on is taking this entire portfolio and running it for the purpose of creating a steadily growing income stream. And that means not relying too much on any one type, and that apartment rentals stream falls right into that line. It will not be a huge part of the company. It will be a little bit bigger than it is today, but still small. And the same applies to our retail side. We do have lifestyle centers in here. We have grocery-anchored shopping centers in here. We have basically every kind of retail, other than malls, in here. And that diversity really does help us create the stability that we have, and we're very, very honed to make sure that in all of our business plans that, that's the product that we continue to offer. So I hope that helps.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.
componenttext: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do lose -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there, necessarily, at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we'
componenttext: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do lose -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there, necessarily, at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we've done, with Avalon [AvonlonBay Communities] and may continue to do with Avalon. So it really will depend on the project. It depends unit by unit. But as I say, the whole -- we are very value-added focus. And we evaluate the condo risk, we evaluate the rental risk and -- against what we can get paid for that and make those decisions. So it's really a deal-by-deal analysis that we do.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: Okay.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, many of the shopping center REITs over the last few months have laid out their views of their internal growth projections for the next 5 years. Most were consistent growth rates that were somewhat below what they were generating prerecession. As you
componenttext: Don, many of the shopping center REITs over the last few months have laid out their views of their internal growth projections for the next 5 years. Most were consistent growth rates that were somewhat below what they were generating prerecession. As you look at the Federal portfolio once we get turn past the near-term blips, how do you see internal growth potential of your portfolio, given all the competing forces affecting retail? Do you think you can get back to where you were, prerecession, on a same-store basis?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nathan, as I sit here, whenever it is, May 5, 6 of 2011, I don't see that. I think from an internal growth perspective, I continue to believe that over the long term that we will outperform. But the forces and factors that were in place during '05, '06, '
componenttext: Nathan, as I sit here, whenever it is, May 5, 6 of 2011, I don't see that. I think from an internal growth perspective, I continue to believe that over the long term that we will outperform. But the forces and factors that were in place during '05, '06, '07, they're just not going to be here. And you have to find -- we have to find, and we're looking pretty hard to find other ways than a risk adjusted basis to grow. So again, we'll be relatively better, I very much believe, but 2007 is long gone.

componenttext: Can you put a number to where you think you could be.

componenttext: Yes, I got to tell you, we've seen that -- the Third Street Promenade is great. The future potential of Third Street Promenade is -- it continues to be great. componenttext: No longer a fortress.

componenttext: Well, yes. No longer a fortress, right. And it absolutely has helped in that last block. headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in the first phase, I think we've said assuming we get that T Stop started -- and that is looking more and more likely, not definitive, but more and more likely, that we are prepared to start Phase 1. That Phase 1 will start late this year, maybe ea
componenttext: Well, in the first phase, I think we've said assuming we get that T Stop started -- and that is looking more and more likely, not definitive, but more and more likely, that we are prepared to start Phase 1. That Phase 1 will start late this year, maybe early next year, but we're even trying hopefully to get it started late this year. But the yields will not be sporty, and so they will not add significant FFO for growth from that first $120 million or so that it will be take in Phase 1. The future entitlement build-out, we're certainly very, very bullish about. But doing this first phase right to be able to create this place is important to us. It's just not going to give us a ton of FFO growth. I hope Mid-Pike will, though. And Mid-Pike Plaza will start a year from now or 15 months from now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, can you talk about what you're seeing in regards to small shop leasing today, any positive momentum pickup there?
componenttext: Don, can you talk about what you're seeing in regards to small shop leasing today, any positive momentum pickup there?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Laura, I think we've talked about this when we were together in California. On the small shop side, it is more -- even more than nationally, it is more dependent upon the location. And a lot of the small shop tenants that were really struggling have
componenttext: Yes, Laura, I think we've talked about this when we were together in California. On the small shop side, it is more -- even more than nationally, it is more dependent upon the location. And a lot of the small shop tenants that were really struggling have either gone away or have figured out a way to operate at the sales levels that they are at because they're looking at those sales levels getting more positive. So we are having a much better set of circumstances in being able to renew them. Now most of them, as I was saying before, are not being renewed at anywhere near the increases that they were last year, in the good old days if you will. But they are much less likely to go away. And so while it's still a soft piece, if you will, of the business, it's a very manageable piece of the business. And I suspect if you talked to others that you would see a really big difference based on the demographics and the location of a particular property with respect to my comments. I suggest that I don't believe applies in those secondary and tertiary, where I don't think it's much better at all.

I wouldn't be surprised to see it termed out, a portion of it termed out sometime later this year. But we don't have any immediate need to do that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Bird
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2011 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2011 earnings conference call. 
Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These, and other members of our management team, are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Our first quarter 2011 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the trust's operating and financial performance. This document is currently available on our website. 
Federal Realty is also now on Twitter, and you can follow us for news and updates with our Twitter handle, @FederalRealty.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events our results. 
Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected on such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained.
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but not are limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. 
The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of first quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. First 3 months of 2011 were really quite strong at Federal, with reported FFO per share of $0.99 compared with $0.94 in the first quarter of last year, a 5% increase. If you remember back in last year's first quarter, we took about $0.05-a-share hit for an early extinguishment of debt charge, but we also booked at about $0.05-per-share benefit from the end of the large -- end of a large lease termination fee from Home Depot. Those 2 transactions, more or less, offset last year. And so, with or without them, we'd still be reporting about a 5% increase this quarter.
Now let's dig into the quarter a bit. 91 leases executed for 340,000 feet of space, and new average rents of $30.52, 11% higher than the $27.55 per foot that they replaced. Michaels is replacing Foot Locker at Bala Cynwyd Shopping Center, and LA Fitness is replacing Toys R Us at Laurel Shopping Center, along with a couple of bank pad renewals led the increase. 
There are, certainly, still deals that we're making, where rental rates are moving down. And in my opinion, there will continue to be deals like that for the foreseeable future. But those deals are making up smaller and smaller percentage. 
For example, in this first quarter, of the 91 comparable leases signed, 19 of them rolled rent down. Thus, 21% of all deals done resulted in lower rent going forward. Now when you go back and look at the past couple of years, however, we note that in 2009, 34% of the deals that we did rolled rent down. And in 2010, 29% of them rolled rent down. 
That's a good trend. I'm hopeful that it will continue, although, of course, not necessarily in every quarter.
Occupancy in the quarter remained flat with last year at 93.5%. It was up 30 basis points from year-end at 93.2%. Wish I could say that it's all positive from here on out, but that's not the case as Borders closed 3 locations after the first quarter ended and Blockbuster closed the remaining 5 that they had with us. 
Together, that's over 100,000 square feet of vacancies that will be reflected in the next quarterly closing. And even with some pretty active new leasing going on within the portfolio, we'll almost certainly bring occupancy below 93% at June 30. 
On top of that, we'd still have one more operating Borders store Winwood, Pennsylvania and a couple of A&P Supermarkets, whose future is questionable, and will depend on the bankruptcy proceedings of those companies. And so, there is potential for additional pressure on occupancy.
But having said that, we've got some pretty positive leasing momentum under way, portfolio-wide, particularly on the West Coast. We believe that looking forward from the second quarter on, that we'll have more upside potential than downside risk in terms of occupancy.
The other important measure to look at is same-center growth, and those metrics are pretty good, too. The quarter, same-center growth was 1.8% without redevelopment and shows a negative 1.1% including redevelopment. Or if we dig a little deeper, you'll see that, that negative 1.1% reflects a Home Depot lease termination fee last year that I mentioned earlier. Without it, same-store growth was 2.5%, pretty darn strong.
Okay. Let me talk about capital deployment a bit and give you an update on development and opportunities on the acquisition front. Let me start out west and tell you that at Santana [Santana Row], our ability to create significant value, largely on the residential side, is looking particularly promising.  As Jeff noted out that 8 years after we opened the property, it has become the social and shopping hub of San Jose. 
As you may recall, we have entitlements to build 1,200 residential units on this site, the first 200 of which we converted to condos years ago. The next 300, we currently operate at as terrific luxury apartments, where upward pressure on rents brings great future growth, leaving roughly 700 units left to build. 
Construction continues on budget, on time for the next 108 rental units -- rental apartments, and we'll begin leasing over the summer, with the first move ins this fall. What was initially expected to be a 7% going-in yield is looking more like an 8% at that $34 million project. 
We're 1 month or 2 away from bringing plans for the next 200 units set to investment committee, with construction starting within the year. After that, we still have nearly 300 units to add.
We're also closing -- close to nailing down the contract for a sizable property acquisition on the West Coast, and redevelopment plans at Westgate Mall in Hollywood are taking shape. All in all, I feel very good about the future of our West Coast portfolio.
Coming back East, we closed on the acquisition of Tower Shops outside of Fort Lauderdale in the first quarter and early indications of tenant interest is exceeding our expectations. That's going to be a good one. 
The real opportunities on the East Coast lie in the prospective development of Mid-Pike Plaza and Assembly Row in the next couple of years, both of which are progressing well at this point. Mid-Pike will, of course, provide better yields in the early phases, but longer-term possibilities at Assembly are encouraging. 
Of course, first things first, and that means the T-Stop needs to get under construction under terms that we can live it. Earlier this week though, the Massachusetts Transportation Authority [Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority] officially puts the T [T-Stop] out for bid, another important step in a very critical process of getting public transportation to the site. 
We would hope to have a strong indication of costs, terms and schedule on that in the next 90 days.  
Lots of smaller redevelopment projects. Many of them with a residential component are moving well through the planning stages, too.
In summary, despite what remains a very challenging retail leasing environment, it is an improving one and our path to future real estate value creation is becoming clearer and clearer. It will be led by retail and nonretail development and retenanting opportunities, along with new raw material in the form of some powerful acquisitions.
That's all I've got for my prepared remarks this morning. I'd now turn the call over to Andy, and I'll look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy and solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollovers throughout the economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. Federal Realty had a very solid first quarter based on steady occupancy and solid rent starts coming from strong lease rollovers throughout the economic downturn. I'll go through results, lay out the anticipated financial impact of the Borders and Blockbuster bankruptcies, talk a little bit about the balance sheet and then, provide a few comments on our outlook and guidance.
Turning to our quarterly results. Rental income grew a solid 3% in the quarter, roughly half of which came from the same-center pool, with the rest coming from acquisition of Huntington Square last August and Tower Shops in January. 
Same-center rental income growth was driven by the year-over-year impact of redevelopment stabilizations including Hampden Lane in Bethesda and rents starts including Neiman Marcus Last Call Studio and Matchbox at Congressional [Congressional Plaza], strong core rental growth, once again, demonstrating the quality of our properties.
Other property income declined by $3.8 million, largely coming from the final Home Depot lease term fee at Flourtown Shopping Center at Philadelphia in first quarter 2010. 
Property expenses were flat year-over-year, as lower expenses associated with snow were offset by smaller increases in real estate taxes. As Don discussed, same-center property operating income grew 1.8%, excluding redevelopment, and was 2.5% including redevelopment after adjusting for the lease term fee in first quarter 2010.
Below the operating line, we saw decreases in net interest expense driven by the repayment of our term loan in first quarter 2010 and the associated $2.8 million charge for early extinguishment of debt, as well as the repayment of our $75 million 4.5% notes in February 2011, utilizing our line of credit. 
First quarter 2011 results also include a positive $300,000 debt extinguishment impact associated with the early repayment of the mortgage debt assumed in the acquisition of Tower Shop.
G&A increased $600,000 through increases in acquisition and personnel costs, as we did preliminary work in getting a number of those future redevelopment opportunities tuned up for execution. 
All in, FFO per share was $0.99 per share, up 5.3% versus first quarter 2010.
First quarter operating results included full rent and recovery charges at all 4 of our Borders and our 5 Blockbuster locations, totaling about $1 million in the quarter. With 3 of our 4 Borders locations and all 5 Blockbuster locations now closed, we'll have an incremental 103,000 square feet of vacancies starting in the second quarter and anticipate rent and recoveries totaling 600,000 for the remainder of 2011 from those spaces. 
These negatives will certainly be offset by positive impacts including year-over-year improvements from Hampden Lane in Bethesda and the 300 Santana Row, both most Dick's [Dick's Sporting Goods] and Ross coming online at Escondido, as well as a slew of other core lease deals. 
While we reaffirmed our 2011 guidance, we expect some lumpiness in our quarters to achieve the full year result.
With respect to the balance sheet, we implemented an at-the-market equity program in March and successfully issued 48 million of common equity in the quarter. We believe the ATM provides cost-effective access to capital, to fluid lease funds' smaller capital needs, and we utilized that program to permanently fund a significant portion of the Tower Shops acquisition in the first quarter.
Over the course of the quarter, we repaid the $75 million 4 1/2% unsecured notes at maturity, and repaid the $32 million Federal Deposit loan on April 29. 
We remain on track to recast the upsized credit facility in June and have been encouraged by the strong positive momentum in the pricing of credit facilities over the past few months. 
The balance sheet remains in great shape, with strong leverage and coverage metrics and significant debt capacity, especially with respect to secured debt, providing a competitive advantage when sourcing acquisition opportunities. 
With another quarter behind us, we're feeling more and more confident that our 2011 FFO per share growth will be comparable to what we saw in 2010, despite the negative impact of the bankruptcies both Don and I mentioned. As a result, we're leaving our FFO per share guidance unchanged. 
Key drivers include: We continue to call for positive full year same-store property operating income growth, despite near-term declines in occupancy and an over $5 million decline in expected lease term fees; G&A will be higher in 2011 than in 2010, call it $500,000, resulting from increased acquisition costs, personnel costs and early stage redevelopment expenses. 
Finally, we're calling for improvements in year-over-year net interest expense. The largest portion of this results from the $3 million swing in early extinguishment of debt that we saw in the first quarter, but also anticipates the repayment of our notes and secured debt throughout the year. 
Operator, I'll now turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from the line of Quentin Velleley, Citi.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular, the Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot of West Coast acquisitions you're looking at. I'm just curious, given the st
componenttext: Don, you spoke about the strength in residential, in particular, the Santana Row property and the future developments you've got there. And I think I also heard you mention a lot of West Coast acquisitions you're looking at. I'm just curious, given the strength in residential, are you more tempted to buy assets with a greater residential exposure or maybe more development sites to take advantage of some of the strength?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Quentin, first of all, the -- we do like mixed-use, and we've liked mixed-use for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana, that's what you see at Assembly. And even some of the redevelopment projects that we have in our shopping center
componenttext: Well, Quentin, first of all, the -- we do like mixed-use, and we've liked mixed-use for a long time. And that's what you're seeing at Santana, that's what you see at Assembly. And even some of the redevelopment projects that we have in our shopping centers like Congressional Plaza, we're looking hard now at adding another residential component to the back at Congressional Plaza. And that's -- all of that is kind of natural in a company that really focuses on the infill location sites that we have. So yes, you look forward at over the next 5 to 7 years, and certainly, the residential opportunities in terms of mixed-use and things like that, make some sense. But we're not going to go out there and -- we're not going to go compete with the residential companies by buying purely residential projects. The difference is, you'll see us maybe more willing to invest our capital in the residential component of the retail projects that we already have. I think the best way to say it is today, our -- the residential income stream within the total rent stream of Federal is 7% or so. You can certainly see that going up 10% or 11% or 12%, but we will always be a retail company.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market. There's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in certain real estate markets, given long-term fiscal austerity risks and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of the DC market. There's been a lot of talk on potential slowdowns in certain real estate markets, given long-term fiscal austerity risks and its impact on the economy. I'm just keen on your thoughts on that topic.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. Now that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall cas
componenttext: Well, look, I don't think I'm saying anything new here. I absolutely believe that the country is over-retailed. I just really believe that there is more space than there is demand for nationally. Now that doesn't apply everywhere, but it is an overall case that I think is true. So when you look at -- when you get down to the specific markets and you have government certainly trying to skinny down, I mean let's start with the federal government, you could say, "oh gosh, Federal's got a big concentration in DC." Are you worried about what's going on with the federal government in terms of its impact on DC? And frankly, I see it the other way. I think there'll be more consolidation to DC in government agencies from other places. And so you really got to look at the specific markets. And in the markets that we're operating in, I don't have that worry, Quentin, no.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's interesting.
componenttext: Okay, that's interesting.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted
componenttext: Don, could you talk a little bit about your new hire, Michael Khouri? I know that you in the past have said, you wanted to explore the avenue of bringing some more mall-based tenants to your properties, but this seems like a much more definitive concerted effort to follow up on that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig, it is. If you go back , if you -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing -- you can't just hit the supply side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael
componenttext: Yes, Craig, it is. If you go back , if you -- I think it proves that I really do believe in the notion of being over-retailed. And if you're over-retailed, the first thing -- you can't just hit the supply side, you got to hit the demand side. And Michael is all about creating demand within our portfolio. Now our portfolio, as you know, was very unique. It is infill. It does have to have some good demographics. And it does have a big advantage in that our--tax, and our extras are demonstrably lower than the comparable mall. Now they're higher, it's higher in a lot of the other shopping centers companies, so it's a lot lower than a comparable mall. So from my perspective, to the extent we can truly use Michael's 26 years of history with General Growth and with Ralph's and with those relationships in the malls to make that pitch, whether you're talking about Pentagon Row compared to Pentagon City or White Marsh compared to the White Marsh Mall or a dozen other places like that throughout the country, having somebody with those relationships that we just don't have to the depth that Michael does, thus to be able to create additional demand. And even if we don't pull those tenants out of the mall, we'll be creating more demand for our existing tenant against our existing tenants and may very well impact -- should very well impact our ability to renew existing tenants. So demand's a good thing and we absolutely made -- took a definitive step here. With looking at our properties, looking at the advantage of our properties compared to the corresponding malls and we're going to try to create demand.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. I look forward to seeing how that plays out. I guess it will take some time, but -- and you also hired Lance Billingsley. Is that because there's more movement in the anchor space? Or you're just trying to give Chris [Chris Weilminster] a life and
componenttext: Great. I look forward to seeing how that plays out. I guess it will take some time, but -- and you also hired Lance Billingsley. Is that because there's more movement in the anchor space? Or you're just trying to give Chris [Chris Weilminster] a life and who just can't take his vacation?

componenttext: Don't worry about Chris. But no, no, it is -- there is no question that we want the ability to handle more anchor stuff and be able to use Chris on more on the acquisition side, more on the management role. Yes, it's just about getting some help. There's a lot going on right now. It's really a pretty exciting time. It's not 2007, but it's much tougher than that, that's for sure. But managing through these next couple of years is going to differentiate some of it a little bit, I think.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory, anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there w
componenttext: I'm personally looking forward to the quarterly conference call when I can say something different than I've said on every previous call, in recent memory, anyway. But unfortunately, I can't. I mean there's certainly more deals to look at now than there were a couple of years ago, but there's not an abundance. And in the markets and the trade areas within the markets where we want to buy property, it just remained very, very competitive to find good assets that we think we can add value to over time. And I don't really see that changing for a while. Returns are very low, and we're still-- certainly more optimistic than we were, but very cautious on the fundamental side of the business and always really looking hard at how we're going see real rents grow in the future in these trade areas. So there's stuff out there certainly. It's just that it's tough to get the good properties and when they come up, they're expensive.

componenttext: It isn't sizeable.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we did not. There's some more woods to chop. Let us get through that -- let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do
componenttext: No, we did not. There's some more woods to chop. Let us get through that -- let's get through that process. If we have something to tell you more, we will. The real issue that we're seeing really comes down to the underwriting assumption. And I really do think we've got a pretty good handle on what rents are. I think we've got a pretty good idea where rents are going. I think we do a pretty good job of redeveloping. And some of the assumptions that are being made in some of these potential acquisitions,  just -- it's hard for us to get ourselves behind them. So that, for me, is the single biggest thing that's stopping it. But in the one we're looking at, we're pretty far down the road. But again, we still have some wood to chop there. You'll see what I -- you'll see what we mean, if we can get down with the closing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And then just last question for me. In terms of just where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise, but obviously, the spreads are -- have held
componenttext: Helpful. And then just last question for me. In terms of just where we are in the cycle and I guess the recovery in leasing spreads. I know, Don, you're sort of cautious by nature and don't want to overpromise, but obviously, the spreads are -- have held up pretty well and you guys have seen probably a more of an increase relative to other companies. But can you give us some sense of just your expectations for maybe the balance of the year or as you look forward, where you think leasing spreads could go?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, more of the same. I don't think you'll see -- I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters, that's for sure. I think the single-digit area is more of what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in prospective comments that is t
componenttext: Yes, more of the same. I don't think you'll see -- I don't think you should expect 11% for the next 3 quarters, that's for sure. I think the single-digit area is more of what you'll see. The real thing I was trying to say in prospective comments that is the really interesting dynamic, from my perspective at least, is when you do look at a bunch of leases done and you say, "Well, okay, within that portfolio of leases done, how many of them are really rolling down?" That really has been where we've seen a real, demonstrable change in the last 2.5 years. There were far more deals that were rolling down than there are now. It's moderate. Now on the other side, it's not like we're seeing big increases like we saw before. Those increases are still lower. But without the bottom pulling down so much there, it's obviously popping up and looking a lot better. It's a more of a moderating leasing environment than it is an extreme one, at least in our portfolio, and that's the big difference.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Helpful.
componenttext: Great. Helpful.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments. A sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop about 7 or 8 because you already own the d
componenttext: Don, just want to circle back on the apartment comments. A sort of a multipart here. As you guys think about apartments increasing as a percent of Federal's NOI, I guess 2 things. One is if you're able to develop about 7 or 8 because you already own the dirt and you can sell some of those for sub-5, that's a pretty significant profit margin and obviously, it's a good backdrop right now to sell apartments. So one is curious about just from a capital recycling perspective, crystallizing the value that you guys create, and two, as you think about NOI volatility, certainly, apartment NOI streams are a lot more volatile than shopping center -- than your shopping center portfolio. So just curious about how you think about those 2.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, those are good questions and hand in hand. You should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building -- and let's talk about Santana because there is -- that is the biggest piece of -- that's being built at condo spec. And
componenttext: Sure, those are good questions and hand in hand. You should know -- let me handle the first one first. Everything that we're building -- and let's talk about Santana because there is -- that is the biggest piece of -- that's being built at condo spec. And these are nice units. And I agree, because we have costs back or land costs back to 2000 -- 1997, '98, 2000. You've got -- we're at an advantage. We plan on, certainly, the units that we're building now, the 108 and probably, the next set, too, at the appropriate time, monetize and get paid for it. And when we started this, what we knew is that you can't time that exactly right. You never can. So to the extent we can rent them and even earn a 5.5% or 6% return until we can monetize with condos, we would. It's turning out that our timing is particularly good, for once, in Santana, and we're able to get better rental yields. But the long-term plan is exactly as you had laid out. Secondly, with respect to NOI volatility, you're absolutely right. And one of the things that we pride ourselves on is taking this entire portfolio and running it for the purpose of creating a steadily growing income stream. And that means not relying too much on any one type, and that apartment rentals stream falls right into that line. It will not be a huge part of the company. It will be a little bit bigger than it is today, but still small. And the same applies to our retail side. We do have lifestyle centers in here. We have grocery-anchored shopping centers in here. We have basically every kind of retail, other than malls, in here. And that diversity really does help us create the stability that we have, and we're very, very honed to make sure that in all of our business plans that, that's the product that we continue to offer. So I hope that helps.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

componenttext: Let me just ask, Don, you've mentioned the condo sales. What about just selling them to an apartment guy and let them deal with the condo risk? And just right now, you could crystallize the aggressive bid for multifamily.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do lose -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there, necessarily, at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we'
componenttext: We prefer not to do that in some of our larger mixed-use projects because we do lose -- we don't really want to have another apartment operator in there, necessarily, at the places that are just stable like at Santana. At Assembly, that's exactly what we've done, with Avalon [AvonlonBay Communities] and may continue to do with Avalon. So it really will depend on the project. It depends unit by unit. But as I say, the whole -- we are very value-added focus. And we evaluate the condo risk, we evaluate the rental risk and -- against what we can get paid for that and make those decisions. So it's really a deal-by-deal analysis that we do.

componenttext: Nathan, as I sit here, whenever it is, May 5, 6 of 2011, I don't see that. I think from an internal growth perspective, I continue to believe that over the long term that we will outperform. But the forces and factors that were in place during '05, '06, '07, they're just not going to be here. And you have to find -- we have to find, and we're looking pretty hard to find other ways than a risk adjusted basis to grow. So again, we'll be relatively better, I very much believe, but 2007 is long gone.
